text: Crewman EPPS (29), wearing a life vest and tool belt, jum down into the darkness. She stands in a great hollow cave oily, wet, resonant with the sound of creaking, rusty ste and WATER MOVING OVER ITS HULL on the other side.

Epps comes to a low point in the darkness, shining her li on a lake of salt water sloshing against the bulkhead. Sh kneels. As the water sloshes back she sees that it is lea in through the seams in the steel plate of the hull.

Epps pulls herself onto the deck from below. She stands o rusting 5000 ton tank barge being pulled in the open ocea by a brawny marine tug at the end of a 150 foot tow cable It is a typical summer day in the southern Bering Sea, wh means a healthy chop and a stiff cold breeze out of the n west.  She closes the hatch behind her and makes her way  forward.

Up ahead, the tug pulls steadily, grey-black clouds of di smoke rising from its massive turbine vents. Epps cinches and checks her body harness, focused and  professional. The product of a rocky childhood in the Pac Northwest and a few years of hard living, she's found her true calling now. And under some grime, several polypro s and a pair of orange men's Insulite pants she might even considered pretty. She clips her harness into the tow cable where it attache to a heavy pair of eye cleats at the bow. She climbs onto the cable, hanging out over the water as it breaks on the bow beneath her. She pulls herself forward on a roller be that fits over the width of the cable and starts off towa the tug at the other end.

DODGE and GREER look on from the stern, where the boat's  name "Arctic Warrior" is emblazoned on the transom. Dodge (37), scruffy chief engineer, wearing de rigueur greasy  coveralls and nicotine stained fingers, is an expatriate  Texan and former merchant marine. GREER (42), is the boat first mate, African American, originally from some swelte red-neck hellhole, now a tug pilot intentionally well to north. They watch as Epps pulls herself toward them, the cable  occasionally dipping a few feet with a spray of water as passing swell slackens it. Epps pulls herself to the ster where the cable winds into a tow anchor.
It's a slow leak. She unclips and drops to the deck.
What's slow?
Maybe twenty gallons an hour.
Where from?
Amidships starboard at the beam.   Just under the waterline. I don't  think it's a problem.
Hear that, Dodge? Epps don't think  it's a problem.
I'll sleep good tonight knowing that.

The view from the pilothouse commands 360 degrees as rada and GPS navigation displays glow. MURPHY, the ship's mast pilots the boat. He is 48, at sea all his adult life, and most of the rest, a fact written on his face and one that every crewman who's ever worked for him has been willing bet his life on. A walkie-talkie CRACKLES AWAKE.
Greer to Murphy.
(lifting the radio)
Go. Murphy turns back to see Greer, Epps, and Dodge looking u at him from the stern.
The number nine on the starboard  side's half flooded. Epps says it's  a slow leak just under the waterline,  about twenty gallons an hour. They  must've pumped it before we left  Sitka.
Of course they did.
Let the buyer beware.
What do you say, Dodge?
(taking the radio)
If it started out at twenty an hour  the piece of shit'd be at the bottom  of the Gulf by now. Whether it'll  make St. Lawrence is anybody's guess.
HIGH AND WIDE as the Arctic Warrior pulls the barge again the swell of a grey ocean and a darkening sky.

The shores of St. Lawrence Island open into a small port  town of mainly pre-fab buildings as the Arctic Warrior  approaches with the barge, now pathetically listing to on side as it moves into the harbor.
A smaller harbor tug helps the Arctic Warrior jockey the  listing barge to the dock as Epps and Dodge jump off to t her up.
Greer feathers the tug into position and shuts down the  turbines.
Murphy jumps down from the pilothouse to the deck as a fa Russian man, Vasili (60) and a MECHANIC in grease-covered orange coveralls approach from the dock.
I thought you say Tuesday.
Better late than never.
(seeing the listing  barge)
What's this?
You got a leak in the number nine  compartment.
No, no. You got leak.
You pump it out and re-seam the hull,  she'll be good as new.
That cost me twenty grand at least.
Fifteen, at the most.
Twenty. You knock off twenty and  then we see. After my guy looks at  it.
In a prefab office with a view of the shipyard, Vasili cu a check as Murphy and Greer look on. He tears it out of t book, handing it across the desk to Murphy, who inspects
You're kidding, right?
You want fair pay, make hamburger  for Mickey D. Otherwise, please to  sign. Vasili pushes a transfer register toward him. Murphy sign
Greer and Murphy walk back toward the dock.
Not bad for dragging a leaky tub  half way to Russia.
He'll sell the scrap for three times  what he paid.
I must be in the wrong business.
You got that right.
(imitating Vasili)
Better than "making hamburger for  Mickey D."

A typical port town bar. Except this one is on an island the middle of the Bering Sea. Epps lines up a shot at the pool table as a couple of SEAMEN check out her ass and a  tattoo of Wiley Coyote poking out of her pants. Greer rea a paper near-by. Murphy enters, crossing to the bar where Dodge nurses a b and a cigarette. Murphy throws down an envelope with Dodg name on it. Dodge picks it up, thumbs through a thick sta of hundreds.
Much obliged, skipper.

The place is a little more crowded now as Epps pushes her way through to the bar, a cigarette dangling from her mou She buys two beers and pays the BARTENDER from her envelo of cash. She takes the beers back to the far wall where a young off-duty COASTGUARDSMAN stands. He takes one, they  laugh.
Beers, cigarettes and pay envelopes on the table before t Dodge, Greer and Murphy look on at Epps across the room, is showing the coastguardsman a birthmark on her neck.
Looks like Epps' gonna get some  tonight.
With that coxswain dickhead.
You aren't jealous, are you Dodge?
Are you kidding me? Jealous? Epps?   Gimme a break. Greer and Murphy trade looks as Dodge raises his beer.
What a laugh. A MINOR COMMOTION can be heard as they sit there.
I'll show you, bitch! They look over to see the coastguardsman's GIRLFRIEND, la 20s, hefty in a red miniskirt and big hair.
You want to mess with me, I'll kick  your bitch ass, girl.
Epps coolly puts out her cigarette as a circle has gather around her and the girlfriend, anxious to see a girl figh
I don't know what you're talking  about. I just bought this guy a beer.
This "guy" is my man, honey.
Darlene --
You, shut up.
(starting off)
Listen, I don't want any trouble,  okay -- ?
(stopping Epps)
Uh-uh. No. We're gonna fix this right  now.
(stepping up)
What seems to be the trouble, ladies?
Whyn't you mind your own business,  chief. Murphy turns to see a shipyard RIVETER, a big man holding beer, still wearing his welding leathers. Murphy turns ba to Epps and the Girlfriend.
As I said, what seems to be the  trouble?
Didn't you hear me, grandpa? Or you  got your hearing aid turned down?
I heard you. But I'm choosing to  ignore you. Epps, let's go. Epps starts forward but the Riveter stands in her way, ta Murphy by the collar.
These ladies was having themselves a  discussion and you're interrupting  it.
You got about two seconds to get  your paws off me, Tarzan.

Or what? Or WHACK! Murphy can't help but wince as a pool cue break in two over the Riveter's head. Dodge, cigarette in his mouth, takes a look at the cue ha he still holds, shaking his head. The Riveter's hands fall from Murphy's collar and his leg buckle. Some of his BUDDIES hold him up as Greer reminds  some of the others he's holding a pool cue of his own.
Epps? He looks to Epps like let's get the hell out of here. She grabs her coat.
Wait. Epps holds there as the Coastguardsman steps up to his  girlfriend.
Darlene. It's over. He gives her the ring from his finger. Murphy rolls his e as the others look on.
I don't love you anymore. Darlene breaks into tears as they all look on, some pat h on the back.
(to Epps)
Come on, Candy. Let's get out of  here. The Coastguardsman takes her by the hand. Epps looks to M and the others as he leads her out.
Murphy, Greer, and Dodge ready the tug to leave as Epps  approaches on the dock. She jumps down onto the deck, a s in her step and a song in her heart.
Morning everybody.
Show your tatoos to that coxswain  last night, did you Epps?
Showed him a hell of a lot more than  that.
I bet you did.
Candy?
It's my pen name.
Murphy throttles up the turbines and backs the tug away f the dock as Greer studies the dawn sky.
Red sky at night, sailor's delight.
Red sky in morning, sailor take  warning.
As the tug turns into the harbor channel, the sun rising  under a cloud bank of brilliant red and orange.
Dodge and Epps play cards at the galley table.
Fuck it. He puts down his hand. Epps takes another drag from her  cigarette, collecting her winnings.
One more?
Why not. She gathers the cards, shuffles.
What is your first name?
What?
It just occurred to me I don't know  your first name. All this time and I  don't know it. She deals the cards in silence.
(finally)
Maureen.
What?
Maureen.
Maureen? She looks on at him as he holds there, takes his cards.
What's yours? Dodge takes a drag from his cigarette, thinking about it.
Roger.
Roger?
Yeah. She wants to laugh, but only studies her cards.
You think that's funny
(lying)
No. She takes a hit from her cigarette as she plays her hand.
THE SONG "SOS" BY ABBA BLASTS as the tug plows westward  through a steady chop and a mild swell.
The MUSIC COMES FROM HERE. Greer has the CD player cranke as he mans the helm in the glow of the pilothouse. He che the radar, holds there a beat. He turns the MUSIC DOWN an picks up a walkie-talkie.
(into walkie)
Greer to Murphy. Greer studies the radar display as he waits.
Yeah.
There's a large vessel out about ten  miles to the north-west.
Murphy sits at his desk over the ship's log, holding his  radio.
I been watching it for close to an  hour and it hasn't moved. I can't  raise it on the radio either. Makes  me think it might be in trouble.
Alright. I'll be right up.
CLOSE ON RADAR DISPLAY as the sweep-refresh reveals a bri point of light in the middle of nowhere.
Merchant vessel at position one seven  four one five west, five seven seven  five north. Murphy holds the radio mic as Greer looks on, Epps and Do standing back.

This is tugboat Arctic Warrior whiskey  alpha sierra bravo four zero niner  two. Over. Only the quiet hiss of white noise comes back from the ra speaker as the bright point flashes on the radar screen.
(to radio)

Merchant vessel at one seven four  one five west, five seven seven five  north, this is tugboat Arctic Warrior  whiskey alpha sierra bravo four zero  niner two. Over. Again, only white noise comes back as the point flashes o the screen.
Too deep to anchor out there.
Looks like it's adrift.
Could be a fishing boat.
Too big. More like a freighter.
What the hell would a freighter be  doing up here? It's way out of the  lanes. There's not a port for 800  miles.
Smugglers maybe.
Smuggling what? Tundra grass? A beat as Murphy holds there. He raises the radio mic.
Merchant vessel at position one seven  four one five west, five seven seven  five north, this is tugboat Arctic  Warrior. Do you copy? Over. Again, only the quiet hiss of static comes back.
Call the Coastguard?
Steer to one eight five. Let's check  her out.
The Arctic Warrior cuts a foamy break in the ink black wa
CLOSE ON RADAR DISPLAY as the phantom point flashes close Murphy looks on as Greer pilots, Dodge and Epps watching.
Alright. Back it off. Greer throttles back and the boat slows.
Hit the lights.
The halogen flood lights flare to life, brilliantly  illuminating the water in front of the boat.
The four of them look intently into the darkness beyond t light. Murphy reaches for the spot control, sweeping a br beam of light with a joy stick.
As the tug moves along, servo motors sweep the searchligh over the bow of the boat and into the darkness.
They peer into the night beyond the boat as it slowly mov when a shadow looms into view.

Whoa, whoa. Greer throttles down all the way and they drift, as the s looms bigger before them in the light from the boat. As they approach, the shadow appears to be a giant rustin bow, rising up from the water, disappearing in the darkne above them. Murphy sweeps the searchlight to reveal more what appears to be a large, darkened ship. As they come  around, the name "CHIMERA" can be seen above the anchor  alleys.
"Chimera." Murphy reaches for the mic, hits the LOUD HAILER.
Chimera.
The tug is dwarfed by the massive rusting hulk of the Chi rising above it.
This is civilian tugboat Arctic  Warrior. Is there anyone aboard? The quiet rumble of the tug's turbines is the only sound.
Murphy raises the mic again.
Chimera, I am hove to at your port  bow. Is there anyone aboard? They wait, looking on at the silent, darkened ship under glare of their lights.
Epps, come with me. You guys sit  tight.
Epps and Murphy, in heavy parkas, climb a hydraulic deck  crane up to the Chimera as Dodge man's the controls again the movement of the water.
Greer holds the tug steady as Epps and Murphy can be seen making their way up under the floodlights.

Murphy pulls himself up and jumps down onto the deck. Epp jumps down behind him. Murphy throws his light up on the  superstructure. All remnants of paint have been rusted ov lending a still darker ominousness to it.

Murphy and Epps move cautiously along, shining their ligh as they go. Despite the omnipresent corrosion, everything seems to be in order. The decks are clear and there is no apparent damage. They come to a hatchway. Epps shines her light down the darkened passage. Murphy moves in.
Murphy and Epps move down the passageway. Even the walls here are rusted. They come to a flight of stairs.
Greer and Dodge wait. Greer reaches for his radio.
(into radio)
Talk to me, skipper. After a moment, Murphy comes back on the radio.
We're in a stairwell just under the  main superstructure.
Murphy and Epps climb the darkened stairway.

This is definitely an old boat, maybe  sixty years old. She hasn't been in  service for at least twenty years.  Probably a lot longer. They top the stairs and walk into a wider passageway whic takes them into an open area. Their lights shine around t revealing sinks and counters and racks of old kitchen  equipment, a few pots still hanging. They move through the galley and into another, narrower,  passageway.
Greer and Dodge look on.
It's funny.
How's that?
Besides a little rust, everything's  pretty well-preserved. Greer and Dodge look at each other.
How she got out here is one hell of  a good question. (a long beat, then)
Jesus. Dodge and Greer hold there, waiting. Only silence from th other end.
What is it? No answer.
Murphy. No answer.
Murphy, goddamit.
(finally)
Sorry. Another beat in silence.
What is it?
Murphy and Epps stand at the top of a stairway, looking o an immense ballroom. Murphy raises his radio.

It's a passenger ship. It's a damn  passenger ship. Though it is dark, there is enough light to see its ornat opulence, tables and chairs in place near a large dance f and orchestra well, and a magnificent crystal chandelier  hanging over it all.
Epps and Murphy climb down the deck crane as Greer and Do meet them at the bottom.
(jumping down)
There's nobody on that boat.
Dodge, Epps, Greer and Murphy sit around the galley table
Probably slipped her moorings, got  tangled up in a current.
Out here? What, so a seven hundred  foot passenger liner drifted out of  Spokane harbor and nobody managed to  bump into her until now?
Somebody's probably looking for her  as we speak.
Whatever the reason, she's adrift  and abandoned. We've got every right  to salvage her.
You mean tow her back? That's a thirty  thousand ton ship you're talking  about.
We've done it before.
Yeah, from one side of the harbor to  the other. But we got half the Bering  Sea and the whole Alaskan gulf to  drag her over.
You have any idea how much a ship  like that could be worth in salvage?  The fittings alone could go for a  few million.
If you get it back in one piece.
It's a risk I'm willing to take.
All we got to do is hit some rough  weather and you can forget about it.
So we cut her loose and wait it out.  A little weather couldn't be anything  she hasn't seen before.
It's a bloody navigation hazard.   One boat can't control a ship that  size.
The damn thing's been floating around  for God knows how long and it hasn't  hit anything yet. So we take it easy.  A little of the old push pull. A long beat as they hold there.
Listen. Forget this job's just a pay  check for a minute. You know I've  been good to you. But I'm prepared  to offer you something better now. (a beat)
If we do this right, it's worth a  lot of money. A lot of money. They hold there looking on at him, waiting.
Go on.
Salvage fees on a vessel like this  could come in around four million  bucks. At least. Who knows, could be  more. Could be a lot more. (a beat)
What I'm proposing is... we split it  four ways. A beat. Dodge looks to Epps and Greer.
Think about it. A million bucks a  piece. (a beat)
You want to spend the rest of your  days drag-assing tank barges on the  gulf coast, fine. Otherwise, let's  get to work.
The tug is tied up alongside the Chimera, whose dark hull stretches off for seven hundred more feet in the light of day.
Murphy brings up the radio mic as Greer and the others lo on.
(to radio)

United States Coastguard, United  States Coastguard, United States  Coastguard. This is tugboat Arctic  Warrior whiskey alpha sierra bravo  four zero niner two. Over. After a moment, a distance-warped, coolly professional, f voice comes back.
Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior, Arctic  Warrior. This is United States  Coastguard Station North Island.  Over.
North Island, I wish to declare myself  salvor-in-posession under section  four two charlie of the International  Maritime Convention.
Affirmative, Arctic Warrior. What  type of vessel?
A passenger liner. Over.
Say again. Over. Murphy looks to the others, almost smiling.
A passenger liner, north island.   Over.
What is the vessel name, registry,  and present position? Over.

Passenger vessel "Chimera." I will  spell: charlie hotel india mary echo  romeo alpha. No registry information  is available at this time. I have  determined to the best of my ability  that the vessel has been abandoned  on the high seas at position one  seven four west, five seven north  at... (checking his watch)
Two zero one four hours zulu time.   Over.
Affirmative, Arctic Warrior. Please  advise your salvage authority pending  registry check. Over.
Roger, North Island. Arctic Warrior  over and out.
Dodge, Epps, Murphy and Greer are standing on the stern o the boat under the power winch.
Okay. We're gonna use a heavier than  usual twin cable rig this time,  consisting of a pair of number three  gauge braided wire tows. (a beat)
We'll tie off through the anchor  alleys. And come down to the aft  port and starboard pins. Here.  Thus,  we need to get two of these... (indicating the cable)
Up there. He indicates the bow of the Chimera.
Seeing as though a foot of one of  these fuckers weighs about a hundred  pounds, it ain't gonna be what you'd  call easy. (a beat)
Any questions?
Supposing one of those cables breaks  under tow.
Then we'll all be doomed. Any other  questions?
Murphy has backed the tug up to the bow of the Chimera. G operates the deck crane, one of Dodge's mammoth cables  dangling from it down to the winch on the stern.
Epps hangs on to the top of the crane as it comes to the  starboard anchor alley in the bow of the Chimera. Dodge p his face out from the other side.
Ready?

Bring it on, dude. Dodge disappears from the hole and his hand comes back wi a smaller pilot cable, which Epps takes and threads throu the loop at the end of the tow cable. She places the end the pilot cable in a vice collar and uses a wrench to tig it down, with the effect of joining the two cables.
Dodge disappears, pulling up the slack from the pilot cab through the anchor alleys.
(finally)
Hit it! Epps reaches over and unhinges the crane hook and the tow cable explosively drops, banging loudly against the Chime hull with a shower of black rust.

Dodge cranks a portable pulley winch on the deck, the pil cable slowly pulling the tow cable up through the anchor  alley. It is heavy and the winch shows the strain as Dodge crank it. He continues, when something gives in the winch mecha and the whole thing slides forward on the pilot cable,  entangling Dodge's leg and dragging him on his ass along deck.
The tow cable creates a spray of rust and smoke as it spi out of the anchor alley before Epps.

Dodge slides toward the anchor alley like a piece of meat toward a sausage grinder, when the winch slams into it an stops dead, the cable continuing on with a loud shriek  dangerously close to his face, until...
The last of the cable explosively whips out of the anchor alley in front of Epps and splashes in the water below. A beat as she holds there.
Dodge? You alright?
Dodge lies tangled in the winch.
Yes!

Two tow cables extend from the Chimera's anchor alleys do into the water and come up again from the water to the to anchor on the tug's stern. Dodge looks on as Greer and Epps stand by. He raises his  walkie.
Alright, skipper, real easy.
Murphy slowly throttles up, moving the boat forward. He t to see as the Chimera drops back behind them.
The tug moves slowly away from the Chimera as Epps, Greer and Dodge look on.
As the tug widens the distance, leaving the Chimera in pl
Murphy holds the helm steady as the Chimera recedes.
Steady as she goes.
Dodge, Epps and Greer look on as the tow cables begin to  rise in their wake.
(into radio)
Throttle back. The tug slows as the cables rise slowly from the water.
More. The tug slows still more.
More. It slows still more, until the tug just creeps along, and the massive tow cables rise entirely out of the water,  straightening as the slack is pulled out.
Some fifty yards behind the tug, the tow cables come taug in the anchor alleys of the Chimera.
Murphy holds the throttle.
Right there, skipper. Right there. Murphy eases forward on the throttle and the turbines ris in pitch.
As the tow cables stretch and the bow of the Chimera inch forward.
The turbines grow louder as Greer, Epps, and Dodge look o at the Chimera behind them, the massive tow cables bowing under their own weight.
Murphy eases forward on the throttle, picking up speed.
The giant ship CREAKS AND MOANS as it starts forward, a s bow break forming on its hull.
The tug is kicking up a foaming wake as it pulls the Chim along behind it. Dodge lets out a hoot, exchanging high f with Epps and Greer.
Murphy smiles as he looks back at the Chimera following  behind.
CLOSE ON A CHART. The south Bering Sea and the Gulf of Al A pencil traces a route.
I figure we go through at the Unimak  Pass here. Refuel at Sanak Island. Greer looks on from the helm as Murphy, Dodge and Epps st over the map table.
With a little extra fuel, weather  permitting, we should make Sitka in  five days without another stop.
Sounds reasonable.
Hypothetically speaking, what if we  get this boat to Sitka and find out  somebody wants it back?
They shoulda thought of that when  they let her float away.
I don't care what, ain't nobody just  gonna let us walk away with a ship  that size.
The law's on our side. If they want  to challenge it, let them try.
They must've scuttled it. Nobody  just lets a ship float away.
Nobody just scuttles a passenger  liner either.
Ever heard of insurance, big boy?
Either way, we found it. It's ours  now -- . An EXPLOSIVE THUD shudders the boat. They look to each ot
(moving for the door)
What the...
Dodge jumps down from the pilothouse as another LOUD THUM

head_text.subj: BLOWS OUT OF THE TURBINE VENTS, SHOWERING OIL OVER THE DE

text: (shouting up to the  pilothouse)
Greer shoves the throttle back.
The boat goes dead in the water, thick black smoke billow from the turbine vents.
as the bow slows in the water, the tow cables coming slac
Dodge pulls open the door. The place is thick with smoke he makes his way to the turbine gauges, Epps and Murphy  behind. Dodge opens the number one turbine cover, looks  inside.
Mother fucker!
What is it?
Threw a turbine blade. Dodge looks over the smoking turbine, pulls back an alumi intake blade, hot to the touch.
Son of a bitch!
Greer, Dodge, Epps, and Murphy confer on the deck.
The number one turbine's pretty well  trashed. Number two runs, but it's  way underpowered.
How long to fix?
Hard to say. I gotta get in there  and have a look. At least a couple  days. Depending.
You think the extra strain caused  it?
Nah. Everything was cool. It's just  one of those things.
The Arctic Warrior floats tied to the side of the Chimera
Dodge has both turbines opened up as he works.
Lights shine on what was once an elegant interior promena Murphy and Greer stand looking on at it.
Some classy tub in it's day, huh?
Yeah.
Check this out.
Epps looks through a file cabinet behind a heavy wood cou as Greer and Murphy approach.
Everything's still here. Ticket  records, receipts, books of account. Greer picks one up.
One first class passage. Elizabeth  James. Dubayy to Halifax. January  29th 1953. Murphy takes it, looking it over.
Chimera. Flag ship of the Dobbins  Kirk Line. Nova Scotia.

Murphy, Epps, and Greer top a staircase out onto a long,  darkened corridor. They move down. Some of the doors are  open, faint light from port holes showing small cabins wi beds, desks, a few chairs.
Murphy, Epps, and Greer come to a hatchway marked "BRIDGE

The forward windows show the expanse of the ocean before  them and the rusting foredeck about 150 feet below. Light from the windows illuminates the bridge as Murphy, Greer Epps look around. Despite a little corrosion and a layer dirt, everything seems in its place.
(looking through  scattered charts and  papers)
I'd sure like to get my hands on the  general log. Epps steps up to the wall, where several framed photos ha
That must be the old man right there. The uniformed man in the photo is a gaunt, stern-looking from another century, with dark, hollow eyes.
Looks like one hell of a stick up  his ass.
He'd let you off at the nearest port,  that's for sure.
A dimming purple horizon is giving way to night as the tu floats under the bow of the Chimera.
Dodge works up to his elbows in turbine 1 as Greer monito a pressure gauge.
How about now?
Sixty pounds.
What? You sure?
That's what it says.
(geting up to have a  look)
Lemme see.
Through the pilothouse windows, the hull of the Chimera  disappears into the darkness beyond the tug's work lights Murphy sits at the chart table as Epps steps in.
Coffee?
(sitting up)
Yeah. Thanks. She brings him his cup, seeing the documents he brought b from the Chimera.
(taking a seat)
What'd you find up there?
Some charts. A crew manifest. (looking them over)
Looks like her last voyage was January  1953. The question is where the hell's  she been since.
She was sailing up north, right?
Her destination was Halifax, yeah.

Well, suppose she got a little further  north than she should have.  Got  stuck in the ice. The passengers and  crew evacuated. She froze into the  ice pack, which moved further north,  where it froze in solid. They write  it off. Fifty years later, the whole  global warming thing happens. The  ice melts, she gets loose and floats  around til somebody runs into her. Murphy nods, considering it.
As reasonable an explanation as any,  I guess. Epps takes a sip of her coffee as she thinks about it.
Ever heard of the Mary Celeste?
Nope.

She was a two-masted brig boat sailing  out of New York in 1872.  One day  she was sighted off the coast of  Portugal by a merchant vessel, the  Dei Gratia. As the crew of the Dei  Gratia got closer, they discovered  that no one was at the helm of the  Mary Celeste. On boarding, they found  her completely deserted. The captain,  his wife, their daughter, and the  entire crew, all gone. The last entry  in their log made no mention of any  trouble. The table was even set for  dinner. And in the nine days after  the last entry, she sailed 700 miles  without anyone aboard.
So what did happen?
Nobody knows. There've been a lot of  theories, of course. But we'll never  really know for sure.
You think she's sailing without a  crew? Murphy looks out at the Chimera off the bow.
I think we'd be surprised where a  drifting ship might wind up with a  little wind and the right current.
You're more practical than  superstitious.
Only way to be. Epps nods, takes another sip of coffee, looking on at the rusting hull of the Chimera stretching off in the light.
Greer operates the crane arm as Dodge directs him. The cr hoists out one of the massive turbine fans onto the deck. Dodge gives him the thumbs up as it comes down easily.
What's this?
Turbine rotor's shot.
I thought you said it was just a  blade.
Metal's crystallized. Gotta replace  the whole deal.
How much longer's that gonna take?
Like I always say --
I know I know, two ways to do anything --
The right way and the wrong way.
But how long?
Hard to say.
We gotta get outa here, Dodge. A  storm blows up and we're history.
I'm telling you, you don't want to  be running that fan like it is.
What about running number two by  itself?
It's a full 2500 horses down. We  couldn't drag that boat down hill on  ice with it.
How long, then?
I gotta pull the blades and re-seat  everything in a new rotor -- .
How long?
Three, four days.
Goddamit, Dodge.
What do you want me to tell you,  that we can throw this sucker back  in and start pulling her like nothing  happened? Can't do it, skipper. A beat as Murphy stands there, knowing he's right.
(from the pilothouse)
Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior, Arctic  Warrior. This is United States  Coastguard. Over. A beat.
Murphy enters the pilothouse as the distance-warped VOICE comes back on the radio.
Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior, Arctic  Warrior. This is United States  Coastguard Station North Island.  Over. Murphy raises the radio mic as Epps, Dodge, and Greer ste in.
(to radio)
North Island, North Island, North  Island. This is tugboat Arctic  Warrior. Over. After a moment, the same professional, distance-warped vo comes back.

Arctic Warrior, we have submitted  your section four two charlie salvage  notification. However, the  International Maritime Authority  record for a passenger vessel Chimera  indicates it was lost at sea in the  Gulf of Oman day two month two year  one nine five three.  Over. A beat as Murphy holds there.
North Island, please repeat? Over.
Arctic Warrior, passenger vessel  Chimera was lost at sea day two month  two year one nine five three.  Over. Another beat as Murphy holds there, as the others look on
North Island, have you got any  additional information? Over.

Affirmative, Arctic Warrior. The  vessel Chimera was registered to The  Dobbins Kirk Line, Halifax.  Nova  Scotia. Date of commission day nine  month seven year one nine three two.  Over. A long beat as the static of the open channel comes back.
Roger, North Island. I am tied to  the passenger vessel Chimera. And  she is afloat. Repeat, she is afloat.  Over.
Roger, Arctic Warrior. I say again,  our records indicate the passenger  vessel Chimera was lost at sea.   Over.
Roger, North Island. Please advise  pending further information. Over.
Affirmative, Arctic Warrior. This is  United States Coast Guard North Island  Station. Over and out. A beat as they hold there, thinking about it.
Obviously it's some kind of screw  up. The shipping records aren't a  hundred percent accurate.
Man, it gives me the creeps. We got  no business towing a ship that size  anyway. I say we fix the turbines  and hit the highway.
Are you crazy? Do you realize we got  ourselves a ship? We own a ship,  Dodge.
Yeah, a ship that's supposed to have  been lost at sea fifty years ago.  You don't think that's just a little  freaky?
If this thing turns out to be a ship  everybody thought sank a long time  ago, we just hit the jackpot.
Yeah, well how the hell you get  something like that wrong? That's a  damn big boat. It's either sunk or  it ain't.
We all want to get outa here, Dodge.  Especially me. With that boat in  tow. You got three days.  Make the  most of it. A beat as Dodge looks back, then out at the Chimera.

A pencil point on a map follows across Saudi Arabia, comi to the Persian Gulf and tracing the coast of the Arab Emi to Dubayy. Murphy sits at his desk over the map. His pencil point fo the Persian Gulf from Dubayy, through the straight of Hor into the Gulf of Oman. Murphy marks an "X" there. A beat he looks on at it. He opens a large envelope he found aboard the Chimera. He empties it on the desk. He looks through it, docking rece from various ports of call, bills of lading, etc. He look over the passenger manifest.
Murphy wakes. He lies on his bunk, having fallen asleep l night in his clothes, still holding the envelope and some the papers inside.
Dodge disassembles the turbine fans on deck as Greer read in the shade of the deck house. Dodge's hand slips and he skins his knuckles.
Fucker!
Take it easy, Dodge. It's only a  piece of metal.
(inspecting his skinned  knuckles)
Damn mind of it's own.
(seeing Murphy)
Morning, skipper. Murphy has stepped out into the sunlight.
Morning.
You're up late.
Guess I must've fallen back to sleep.  Where's Epps?
Went aboard.
She take a radio?
Yeah. Murphy nods. A beat.

Epps steps from a passageway into a large public room. Ta and chairs are scattered haphazardly, light falling in fr windows along the wall where tattered curtains hang. She  walks on. A pair of empty glasses sit on a table, an empty sherry  decanter beside them. An ashtray sits beside that. Epps s reaching down. She pulls back a half-smoked cigarette,  lipstick smudging the end, yellowing and fragile from tim And, as she stands there, we see a FIGURE, IN MURKY  SILHOUETTE, MOVE PAST THE DOORWAY IN THE BACKGROUND. In a instant it is there and gone. She puts down the cigarette, having sensed a presence. Sh turns to the doorway across the room, but there is nothin to be seen now.

A doll's white face, eyes haunting and coldly blue, stare into the middle distance. It lies on a love seat as Epps  steps up. She lifts it. Several other toys lie scattered  about as she studies it, when the sound of a TICKING CLOC CAN BE HEARD. A beat as Epps holds there. She turns, trying to locate t sound. From across the room, Epps stands, listening. As t TICKING CLOCK sounds from here. She turns, putting down t doll, holding a beat. She approaches, crossing the room,  coming finally to a stop before us and what we come to se is an ancient grandfather clock. All but it's minute hand has fallen off its corroded face but from inside it emits a weak though steady TICKING. Epps stands there as the clock ticks, looking on, when th TICKING CEASES. A beat as she holds there, as the clock f her, now silent.
Epps shines her light in the darkness as she comes to a d where daylight falls from a small port. She looks through it.
Epps stands in a white tiled room. Light falls from port  holes high in the wall. Running its length is a small swi pool, it's rusted fixtures and stained surface creating  bizarre patterns.
Epps comes to a row of changing stalls. Old clothing hang there, unused for fifty years. A pair of woman's shoes li on the floor.
Epps moves along, passing through a doorway into

Epps enters another room scattered with old exercise equi circa 1950, a wooden rowing machine, barbells and a medic ball. She steps up to the wall, where pictures hang. The Chimer can be seen in better days, sailing full speed on a calm  sea.

Epps jumps down to a lower deck. She shines her light up see that she is in an engine compartment, showing a massi diesel burner. She passes through into another compartmen where the giant pistons of the ship's power plant rise up the ceiling.

Epps moves, passing still more diesel burners, towering o her in the cavernous space. She moves into a narrowing  passage, piping and machinery ducts winding their way int the depths of the ship. Finally the passage opens into yet another compartment,  apparently a cargo hold. Crates and boxes are stacked on  loading palettes. In the corner, a rotting canvas drape covers something. E comes to it. She lifts the canvas, which crumbles away to reveal a 1951 Ferrari sportster. For the exception of a c of dust and a small amount of corrosion, it is perfectly  preserved. Mail bags lie in piles along the wall, stacked between mo wooden crates and palettes, when something catches Epps'  eye. A heavy, metal door in the wall is twisted on it's hinges as though blown back from some terrific explosive force. Epps approaches, coming to the twisted door. She shines h light inside. A clutter of debris, shelving and wood, are visible in th shadows, when her light catches a glint of something. She swings her light back, revealing a yellowish bright objec between broken wood slats. Epps steps in. She kneels, shining the light closer. The  yellow glint is metal. Epps pulls back a slat, sliding aw some of the debris to reveal that it is cast from a kilog ingot of gold. She reaches out. She raises it, completely untouched by t years. She pulls back still more debris, revealing a stac of gold ingots, some having tumbled to the side. She slid away a large trunk that has fallen, pushing off more junk see that the stack is much larger, perhaps four feet high and five feet across. A beat as Epps stands there, looking on at $50,000,000 in gold.
The debris has been cleared away to reveal a clean 5'x 5' 4' stack of gold ingots.
What the fuck we gonna do with it? Greer, Murphy, Epps, and Dodge all look on.
What the fuck you think we gonna do  with it? It's ours, baby. It's all  ours. Murphy has stepped forward, taking an ingot, inspecting i
How much you figure that's worth,  skipper?
(still looking it  over)
Hard to say. Maybe forty, fifty  million.
Ho, baby!
That's a lot of money for somebody  to just let float away. Murphy looks up at her from the gold.
Yes, it is. A beat as they all hold there.
It's a hell of a lot of money.
What, you think there's something  funny about it?
A ship with fifty million dollars in  gold aboard, adrift? And nobody seems  to care enough to come looking for  it?
If they thought it was lost at sea,  they probably just wrote it off.
Not for fifty million. An ocean liner  maybe. But fifty million in gold,  they come looking for.
Maybe they didn't want it back.   Maybe the whole fat deal was insured.
Maybe. But there's always somebody  whose interest's at stake.
All I gotta say is it looks like  that somebody's us right now. Greer cackles as he high fives Dodge.
And it looks like somebody got here  before us too. The steel hatch is twisted, as from a great hand ripping back from the wall.
(inspecting it)
Didn't happen yesterday, I'll tell  you that. Torn parts rusted bad as  the rest of the boat.
Then it happened before they scuttled  her.
You mean, before she sank.
Cargo like this could make a crew  think twice.
That it could. A beat, as they all look on at the gold.
After dinner, Murphy, Greer, Dodge and Epps sit around th galley table.
Then why didn't they take it.
Probably didn't have time.
Or somebody stopped them.
Either way, they must've had a pretty  good reason.
Must be a damn good reason to jump  ship and leave fifty million dollars  aboard. A beat as they consider it.
So what're we gonna do. That's the  big question, right?
A salvage claim to a vessel's cargo's  as valid as a claim to the vessel  itself. It's ours.
Then we're rich. We're damn, filthy  stinking rich.
It looks like it. A beat as they let this sink in.
So what? We gonna unload the gold  and get a move on?
We leave it where it is. Stick to  the plan.
You gotta be kidding? What the hell  we need that tub for, we got fifty  million bucks?
So we get a little more for the boat.  Besides, the gold'll be safer where  it is.
Yeah, but we still gotta haul that  big piece of shit all the way back  to Sitka.
It's worth the effort. Believe me.   Besides we're gonna need her to prove  the salvage.
Why not call for help?
For now the best thing we can do is  to keep quiet about this.
Last thing we want is extra partners.
Or uninvited guests.
I heard that.
Dodge, you gotta get on those repairs.
Yeah, yeah. I'm on it.
The sooner we get under way, the  sooner we are to spending what's  ours.
Dodge, wearing a welding mask and gloves, braises an alum fitting over one of the open turbines.
Epps finishes stacking the gold ingots in a cleared space beyond the twisted hatch.
Two hundred twenty. Two twenty one. (as Epps stacks the  last one)
Two twenty two. Greer makes a note.
Two hundred twenty two kilograms of  solid gold.
That's what I call a payday.
Hell yeah. They slap hands.
Murphy moves down the darkened passage, coming to a door  marked "CAPTAIN." The door is ajar. He pushes it open.

Murphy stands in the doorway of a spacious cabin panelled dark wood. A large desk occupies a corner of the room by windows. Though dirty and worn with time, everything is  ordered and in its place. Murphy comes to the desk. He sits down in the chair behin it. The surface is clear and uncluttered. He pulls out th drawer to reveal pens, writing paper, a ruler, compass an protractor amidst other sundry items.
Murphy steps in. The room is undisturbed, light falling i on the taught green bedspread through dirty, tattered  curtains.  A robe hangs on the back of a chair. A pair of slippers lie beneath it.

Murphy stands in the bathroom. The tile has yellowed with time, but everything is exactly as it was left. Even the  shaving kit is neatly arrayed on the sink as Murphy looks at it. He looks up, seeing himself in the mirror, when an EXPLOSION SOUNDS.
Murphy comes to the railing, looking out over the bow of ship to see black smoke rising from where the Arctic Warr is tied.
Greer and Epps run to the side to see billowing smoke ris from the Arctic Warrior as Murphy climbs down the crane t the deck.
Murphy jumps down to the deck. Flames belch from an open  hatch as Murphy grabs a fire extinguisher from a deck loc coming to the engine room door.

Murphy enters to find the engine room engulfed in flames black smoke. He finds Dodge spraying at it with an  extinguisher of his own. The flames belch up from an oil fire in the turbine well, the heat searing paint on the metal covers. Murphy sprays cloud of halon and the fire dims, but only for a moment. Dodge grabs another extinguisher, his leg burned, face an hands singed. An EXPLOSION ROCKS THE BOAT and molten flames hurl throug the air, catching Murphy's pant leg. He's so engrossed in fighting the flames, he doesn't realize he's on fire.
(over the roar)
Murphy! Murphy looks down to see his pant leg is on fire, as Dodg turns a cloud of halon on him, putting it out.

Propane tanks're gonna go! Murphy crosses in the smoke, coming as close as he dares the most intense part of the flames. He turns the extingu into them, holding it there. The flames dim, as Dodge joins him on the other side, tur his extinguisher on it too. The fire seems to dim yet aga as clouds of halon rise up. Fire belches from a duct, crawling across the ceiling. Do fires his extinguisher at it, pushing it back across to t wall again. Murphy extinguishes the last of the flames in the turbine well as Dodge brings a snaking tendril of fire down to th deck, and finally out. They stand there in the sudden silence, the air heavy wit smoke. A fine layer of halon powder lies over everything, but the fire is out.
Dodge smokes a cigarette, now starting to feel his burned leg, which is oozing as Murphy and Greer look on.
One minute I'm minding my own  business, the next thing I know the  whole place is burning up. (taking a drag)
An oxygen tank must've blown on the  welder. Started an oil fire.
Looks like it took out the backup  genny too.
Terrific. Epps arrives with a first aid kit.
How's that leg? Epps cuts back the burned pant leg to see the burn.
Seen better -- Ow! Epps cleans the burn with hydrogen peroxide.
This's gonna hurt a little.
Thanks for the warning -- Ow! Damn! Epps keeps cleaning as Dodge bears it.
What now?
We could call for help.
And get a bunch of fools sniffin'  around here?
What other choices have we got?
I tell you one thing, we're not gonna  be towing no ship now.
A gas lantern sits on the map table illuminating Murphy a he holds the radio mic.
(to radio)
United States Coastguard, this is  tugboat Arctic Warrior whiskey alpha  sierra bravo four zero niner two.  Radio check. Over. A moment, then:
Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior, Arctic  Warrior. This is United States  Coastguard Station North Island.  Your radio check is affirmative.  Over.
Roger that, North Island. Arctic  Warrior whiskey alpha sierra bravo  four zero niner two. Over and out.
Dodge pours out a few cans of cold chili into a bowl and  takes it to the table where Epps, Greer, and Murphy sit u the stark light of a gas lantern.
Fifty million four ways. That's twelve  million and change a piece.  What  you gonna do with your share, skipper?
Not much at all, I guess. Retire.   Live out my golden years and all  that.
I'm buyin' me a nice outrigger.   Spend my time hauling rich Seattle  business men through the Puget.
How about you Epps?
Guess I'll just keep working.
What're you crazy?
I like my job.
Greer?
Moving to Sweden.
What's so great about Sweden?
It's a beautiful country. Very clean.  Very civilized. And cold.
That's a good thing?
Hell, yeah. I like it cold. Colder  the better.
Yeah, but not as cold as those Swedish  girls you only gonna dream about.
We'll see who's dreamin', m'man.
Dreamin's all any of you're gonna be  doing if we don't get this boat  running.
Yeah, yeah.

head_text.subj: A STRANGE SOUND BEGINS. IT IS LIKE A DISTANT SHRIEKING, A
OF METAL AGAINST METAL, BUT ALMOST HUMAN, DISTANTLY ECHOI

text: What the hell is that? The SHRIEKING CONTINUES, ECHOING EERILY AS IF FROM THE SE
Dodge, Epps, Murphy and Greer emerge on deck. The DISTANT SHRIEKING IS LOUDER HERE, BUT SEEMS TO BE  EMANATING FROM DEEP IN THE SHIP as they stand facing it o the bow.
It's coming from inside. They hold there listening as the SHRIEKING CONTINUES.
Sounds like the hull.
Warm water current maybe, making the  metal expand.
That shit is seriously bizarre. The DISTANT SHRIEKING ECHO continues as they hold there.
The engine room is black with soot, the turbines covered halon powder. Dodge stands there looking at it. He sighs.
Greer goes through shelves of supplies, finding a stack o sterno cans and warming candles. He throws them into a wo crate of other supplies he's gathered.

Epps slowly pushes open the door. She holds a sack with a few items she's managed to scavenge. Light falls from  curtained windows onto the room. A divan sits against the wall. A table stands in the middle of the room, a moth-ea velvet table cloth sitting under a brass lamp on top. Two twin beds stand on either side. They are covered in dust are moth-eaten, unmade, as if the occupants had just gott up, fifty years ago. In one corner is an armoire. Epps steps up to it, pulling back the door to reveal a rack of woman's clothing hangin there undisturbed.
A pair of slippers lie on the floor beside a chair, over  which is draped a woman's robe. Epps lifts it, the materi crumbling in her hands.

A drawer comes back to reveal a number of personal affect a man's billfold, cuff links, tarnished silver cigarette  holder and case, coins, black horn-rimmed glasses, pocket watch and fob, and a room key. Epps pulls back the billfold. She opens it. Inside she fi a Canadian passport a picture of a dark-haired man with a mustache and black horn-rimmed glasses, circa 1950. In th folds she finds three hundred Canadian dollars. An insert holds pictures, of a suburban home, children, and a woman presumably his wife.

Epps steps from the room. She turns to close the door, bu stops, holding there, strongly sensing something. THE CAMERA SLOWLY COMES AROUND TO HER OTHER SIDE, reveali the long passageway behind her, each bulkhead hatchway  creating the impression of a tunnel of mirrors that frame one another and, standing at the very end of this tunnel the foggy light from a porthole, a MAN in dark clothing. Epps slowly turns her head to see what she already senses the man standing at the end of the passageway facing her. beat as they hold there. The man only stares back at her, then turns to walk away.
Hey! Epps moves off as the man walks around the corner.

Hey, wait a minute! Hey! MOVING WITH Epps as she breaks into a run, going down the passageway. She comes to the corner, rounding it out onto another passageway. The man is nowhere to be seen. Epps moves quickly down the passageway, coming to the nex corner, rounding it out to see only another long passagew She turns back, running right into Murphy.
Take it easy, you'll live longer.
Did you see him?
Who?
The guy. He just came this way.
What guy?
There's somebody else on this boat.
What? What the hell're you talking  about.
I saw him. Just a minute ago. Some  guy.
Are you sure?
Of course I'm sure. I saw him.
You sure it wasn't me?
It wasn't you. It was somebody else.  There's somebody else aboard. A beat as Murphy looks back at her.
Greer, Dodge, Murphy, and Epps stand around by lantern li
Light in those passages ain't so  good.
I'm telling you, I saw somebody. I  don't know who it was. But I saw  somebody.
What'd he look like?
Maybe six feet. Lanky. I didn't get  a good look. He was far away. But I  saw him. I saw him as sure as you're  standing there.
Where's his boat, then? Where's his  crew? He ain't gonna be out here by  himself, that's for damn sure.
She's so big somebody could come  alongside her on the other side and  we'd never know it.
Maybe that is his boat.
Gimme a break. A beat as they sit in silence.
If somebody's aboard her already,  she ain't ours. She's theirs.
Bullshit. That boat hasn't made steam  for fifty years. We found her. She's  ours.
Not in the eyes of the law.
So, we find this guy and make a deal  with him.
We don't exactly have the best  bargaining position.
I say fuck the motherfucker. We're a  professional salvage crew going about  our business. What's some yahoo doing  way out here by himself anyway?
And what do you propose? That we  knock this guy off?
Why not? Why the fuck not? A beat as Murphy, Greer and Epps exchange looks.
Fifty million dollars. Fifty million.  We gonna let this guy just take it  from us? One guy?
So we kill him?
I'm saying we gotta do whatever we  gotta do to preserve our interest.
I don't know.
Let's just take it easy here, alright?  Nobody's gonna kill anybody.
Supposing he wants to get bad with  us?
One guy isn't gonna be so stupid.
Maybe he isn't alone. They consider this a moment.
I say we off-load some of that gold  now.

Would you hold on just a minute here,  please? Look, there's no reason to  panic now. Epps saw somebody. Fine.  It's a big boat.  Chances're real  good he doesn't even know about the  gold. If we stay cool, nobody'll be  the wiser. (a beat)
The gold stays where it is til we're  ready to go. Like I said, it'll be a  hell of a lot safer there than here.
What if that fucker finds it before  we're ready to go?
We'll stand a watch. Four on, eight  off. Low man first.
Guess that'd be me. Again.
Dodge, get on that turbine. I don't  care if you don't sleep for a week.   The sooner you're done, the sooner  we can get out of here. How's the  food situation?
Pretty low all around.
We'll have to take it easy then. I  don't think we'll find much aboard  the ship, but it's probably worth  looking around.
Say we run into this guy again. A beat as they consider this.
If he's reasonable, maybe we can  make some kind of deal. If not.   We'll have to re-consider our options.
Yeah, reconsider fucking his shit  up.
Epps is dressed in her cold weather gear as she opens a  locker, revealing a flare gun and a shotgun. Epps pulls b the shotgun and a box of shells.

Murphy and Dodge look on as Epps loads the last of severa shotgun shells into the pump action short barrel 12-gauge She expertly shuttles a round into the chamber with one h Dodge takes a hit from his cigarette as Greer crosses fro the deck house.
Pretty handy with that scatter gun,  Epps. You raised on a farm?
(setting the safety)
Seen a lota movies.
No cowboy shit up there, understand?
No cowboy shit. Right. Greer extends a thermos to Epps.
Coffee.
(pocketing it in her  coat)
You're a pal. She checks the squelch on her radio, pockets it too.
Got your light?
Yup.
Smokes?
Oh yeah. Her bravado does little to hide her apprehension as she s the shotgun on her back.
See you boys later. (to Greer)
Don't be late, I need my beauty rest. She looks up, climbs onto the crane and up toward the dar ship above them.
A flashlight beam cuts through the darkness as Epps  approaches. If this place is creepy in the daylight, it i terrifying now. She comes to a ladder and climbs down.

Epps shines her light as she passes through, coming to th cargo hold. She crosses in the darkness, her light catchi the tarnished glint of the gold. She comes up to it, stop there, looking on at it, a perfectly symmetrical fortune. She looks around for a place to sit. She drags a palette the bulkhead, settling in to face the rest of the compart She puts her shotgun down beside her and takes out her th to pour herself a cup of coffee.

Epps has dozed off when a CLATTERING ECHOES DISTANTLY  somewhere in the ship. Epps wakes. It is silent, as she h there, not sure she heard anything, when a DISTANT BOOMIN SOUNDS. She reaches out for the shotgun, intently listeni As Epps holds there, another deep BOOMING sounds distantl somewhere. Epps turns, her blood running cold.
Epps moves along in the darkness when the DISTANT BOOMING CAN BE HEARD BRIEFLY AGAIN. She stops, holding there, in silence.
Epps jumps down into the shaft alley where the ship's mas propeller shaft hangs suspended above her. Epps moves alo Finally she comes out into...

Where the propeller shaft extends into a large turbine. S continues on, past huge rusting diesel burners, disappear into the darkness above her, when ANOTHER BOOM SOUNDS. She turns, shinning her light back from where she came.   Nothing moves. Not a sound, but for her breathing and may her heart pounding in her chest. ANOTHER BOOM SOUNDS, aga echoing distantly in the silence. She shines her light th the line of burners. Nothing moves. Epps moves quietly between the burners. She comes to a ma watertight door at the bulkhead. She steps through, findi herself standing between a row of huge oil storage tanks. THE BOOMING SOUNDS AGAIN, closer, as suddenly stopping. She moves on, cautiously walking between the tanks, holdi her light out before her. She comes to the end of the  compartment and another bulkhead. The BOOMING SOUNDS, sti closer. She turns the light into the recesses, showing ru machinery and a stack of oil drums. She approaches, holding the shotgun up. As she nears, the BOOMING SOUNDS AGAIN. She stops. It is coming from here. She tenses, raising the shotgun, holding the light as ste as she can manage. The BOOMING SOUNDS YET AGAIN. It is  metallic and staccato. She stops in the corner beside an oil drum. Several drums have toppled and lie scattered in a pile when a draft sti her hair. She shines her light up to see that she stands the bottom of a giant hatchway shaft rising all the way  through the ship to the top deck and an echoey breeze tha betrays a throughway to the outside. The BOOMING SOUNDS AGAIN, this time coming from the pile oil drums. She steps closer, raising the shotgun, ready t fire. A beat as she summons her courage, then reaches out push a drum with her foot, when A BLUR EXPLODES OUT AT HE She fires the shotgun and a spray of buckshot glances off the steel bulkhead in a shower of sparks, a flurry of fre flapping whizzing by her head as she looks up to see a la albatross flying back up the hatchway shaft toward the to of the ship and freedom.
Murphy to Epps. She settles back, exhausted.
Murphy to Epps.
(taking her radio)
Epps.
You just shoot at something?

Yeah. Just a bird. Just a stupid  bird. She wipes her brow on her sleeve, holding there a moment, when she smells something really awful. She steps forward, following the smell, pushing aside the toppled oil drums to see an unidentifiable form in the be of her flashlight. She steps still closer, training her l on the form to see that it is a human torso.  A large gas runs up its middle and the clothing has been torn by  scavenging birds. She hesitates, then steps still closer when she steps on  something. She starts, then shines the light on the deck front of her where the body's decaying head looks back wi wide, unseeing eyes. It takes everything she has just to hold there. She shine her light back to the headless torso. She shines her light beyond that, and up, to reveal a ben steam pipe hanging out over the deck, stained with dried  blood, a pair of legs dangling from the pipe when, just b her, a booted foot comes into frame, lightly touching her She spins around to see another body above her. Except th one hangs in one piece, suspended from another bent steam pipe. It has been impaled length-wise on the pipe from re to mouth. One of its arms has rotted off and lies on the deck below it.  A few feet away, a third body hangs impaled from ano bent pipe.
A lantern illuminates the impaled bodies and their variou rotting parts.
Ho-ly shit.
Couldn't have happened much more  than a month ago. Greer, Dodge, and Epps look on as Murphy kneels over the  remains of the headless torso.
Bodies're too fresh.
Fresh ain't the first word that comes  to mind. Murphy checks the pockets, finding a wallet. He looks thr it.
Greek citizen. Merchant navy. (standing)
Obviously we aren't the first to  come across this ship. They probably  stumbled across it just like we did.
And look what happened.
Damn barbaric is what it is.
Could be meant as a warning.
Stay away. Or else.
Because of the gold.
That'd be my guess.
So whoever did this might still be  around.
Maybe Epps's mystery man had something  to do with it.
Maybe. A beat as they consider the implications of this.
So, what? We report this? Call the  Coastguard? Another beat as they hold there.
Let's not be too hasty.
Yeah. Hell, what difference does it  make if we report it now or later?   We call this in now, gonna be  Coastguard, FBI, who knows who, all  over the place. A beat as nobody's too sure about this.
Dodge, if this isn't incentive enough  to fix that boat, I don't know what  is.
Dodge fires up a compressor, which feebly comes to life,  turning over the turbine, then sputtering out in a cloud smoke.
All the seals and gaskets're shot.   Anything that was rubber burned up. Murphy stands at the doorway, looking on.
Can't you use something else?
I might be able to find something on  the ship. But it's gonna take time.
Do what you need to do. Just do it  fast.
Right.
Epps sleeps in her bunk.
Dodge and Greer climb down in the darkness.
I need lag bolts, especially one  inch standard. And sheet metal.   Preferably steel, about a sixteenth  of an inch. Aluminium, even tin'll  do.
I ain't no mechanic, just so you  know.
You find anything that even looks  like a compressor. I don't care what,  grab it.

Murphy stands in the cramped room, full of radios and  communications equipment. He looks through the shelves an cabinets, when he opens a drawer to find a dusty bound bo He pulls it back, opening it to see that it is a radio ca log. He takes a seat, paging through it.
Greer works to disassemble a compressor mechanism. He has difficulty getting the right purchase with his wrench, wh he slips.
Dammit! A beat as he inspects his hand. In the silence A DISTANT  SHRIEK SOUNDS, maybe metal against metal or maybe human,  somewhere in the ship. He holds there, listening.
Dodge? He moves on, shinning his light as he goes.
Greer moves along in the darkness when he hears THE SHRIE AGAIN coming from somewhere in the ship.
Dodge!
Greer walks up a stairway, stepping into a darkened  passageway. The SHRIEKING SOUNDS, THIS TIME CLOSER, as it echoes through the ship. He stops, holding there to liste

Greer comes out onto another deck, stopping there. He loo down the passageway a beat, then moves on. He passes thro a hatchway in a bulkhead when A MUSIC BOX CAN BE DISTANTL HEARD. He stops. The song is "DAISY" ("Daisy, Daisy, give your answer do. I'm half crazy, oh for the love of you.") He holds there, listening intently. A door stands open at the other end of the passage. The MUSIC COMES FROM HERE. moves forward, walking toward the end of the passage, and the light falling from the open door.

Murphy pages forward to the last page of the radio call l book. On the page his finger runs down the columns of entries,  coming to "TRANSMISSION 1 Feb 53 21:34 hrs GMT. Engine tr notification made to passing vessel 'St. Charles.'" His finger moves down to the next entry, coming to:  "TRANSMISSION 2 Feb 53 09:52 hrs GMT. Dead in Water.   Notification made to passing vessel 'Normandy.'" His finger continues: "TRANSMISSION 2 Feb 53 14:07 hrs GM Captain relieved of command. Notification made to passing vessel 'China Sea.'"
Captain relieved of command. He holds there a moment, moving his finger down to the fi entry, reading: "TRANSMISSION 2 Feb 53 21:24 hrs GMT. Gen

He turns the page to see only the words "GOD SAVE US" scr in faded red ink. A beat as he holds there, when a CHANNE OPENS WITH A SHORT BURST ON MURPHY'S RADIO. He looks to i but there is no response from the other end. Another SHOR BURST AND THE CHANNEL OPENS AGAIN. This time it remains o but no one says anything on the other end, UNTIL THE CHAN CLOSES AGAIN. Murphy takes the radio.

This is Murphy. Anybody trying to  call me? Over. He waits as no response comes, then THE CHANNEL OPENS AGA Only silence from the other end as someone seems to be th but is not saying anything. Murphy presses the talk butto
Greer? Dodge? Again, there is no response, until the CHANNEL OPENS. Mur holds there as he is answered by silence, WHEN A GRAVELLY

head_text.subj: STRANGELY DISTORTED MALE VOICE COMES BACK ON THE RADIO

text: "Cock-a-doodle-doo," said the rooster  to the crow. "Where are you now? I  know, but won't say so." Murphy is momentarily stunned. He hits the talk button.
Who is this? The RADIO CHANNEL OPENS. Only silence comes back, as if  someone were there but not speaking.
Who is this!! The CAMERA PUSHES IN AS MURPHY LISTENS.
Penny whistle toy. Penny whistle  toy. Penny whistle toy. Penny whistle  toy. The CHANNEL CLOSES as the CAMERA STOPS CLOSE ON MURPHY.   Murphy squeezes the talk button.
Greer! Dodge! Only silence comes back from the radio when A MAN'S BLOOD CURDLING SCREAM sounds from somewhere in the ship.
Murphy moves quickly down the passageway when his radio  sounds.
Dodge to Murphy.
(taking radio)
Murphy.
You better get down here quick,  skipper. I'm on "C" deck. Cabin 400.
What is it?
I think you better see this for  yourself.
Murphy comes down the stairs and into the passageway we s Greer in earlier. At the end, the light from the cabin fa from the open door as he approaches.
As Murphy comes to the door to see Dodge standing in the  middle of the cabin.

I found him like this. Greer is lying supine on the floor. His legs are rigid an his trunk is extended. His arms are flexed and twisted so that the palms are facing away, fingers splayed, wrists  quaking over his chest as they fight to touch each other. Murphy kneels beside him. Greer's eyelids are half closed his eyes rolled up into his head. His jaw is clenched, fa contorted in a bizarre grimace. And he speaks, uttering  nonsense words in harsh expulsions, as though speaking in tongues.
Oragishlaoomnudrasadrafantoshviska  getofedobrodijotosiantosg.
As a light shines in it, the pupil is fixed and dilated.
Hard to say.
Greer lies unconscious on a bunk, now quiet, no longer se as Epps shines a flashlight into his eye, Dodge and Murph looking on. She turns it off, standing upright.
I'm no doctor. But I'd say he's in a  coma.
A what?
I don't know what else you'd call  it. He's breathing on his own, but  his pupils are completely blown out.  He's totally unresponsive to pain. (a beat)
What happened up there?
I heard a scream. When I got there I  found him on the floor. He was having  some kind of seizure. I didn't see  anybody else.
He must've seen something. A beat as they consider this.
Other than the obvious, there's  nothing wrong with him that I can  see, not on the outside.
Then what the hell happened to him? Another beat as they hold there.
Just before I heard him yell there  was somebody on the radio.
Greer?
I don't know. No. Not Greer.   Somebody. Another long beat as they think about this.
It was a man's voice. Repeating some  sort of children's rhyme. I don't  know, it didn't make any sense. You  didn't hear it?
Not me. Another beat as this sinks in.
(looking to Greer)
He needs a doctor.
I'll call us in. Dodge, see how many  signal flares you can scrounge up. (to Epps, meaning  Dodge)
Keep an eye on him.
A gas lantern sits on the map table illuminating Murphy a he holds the radio mic.
(to radio)
United States Coastguard, United  States Coastguard, United States  Coastguard. This is tugboat Arctic  Warrior whiskey alpha sierra bravo  four zero niner two. Over. No response.
(to radio)

United States Coastguard, United  States Coastguard, United States  Coastguard. This is tugboat Arctic  Warrior whiskey alpha sierra bravo  four zero niner two. Over. Again, no response. He holds there, then finally:
(to radio)

Mayday. Mayday. Mayday. To any vessel.  This is Arctic Warrior.  Arctic  Warrior. Arctic Warrior.  Whiskey  alpha sierra bravo four zero niner  two. Last known position one seven  four west, five seven north. I am  afloat and drifting.  Require  immediate medical assistance for one  person, possibly comatose. I am a  one hundred twenty foot civilian  tug, hove to at port bow of disabled  passenger liner Chimera. I repeat,  Chimera. Over. Only the desolate WHITE NOISE OF EMPTY AIR COMES BACK.
Greer lies unconscious as Epps looks on at him. The door  comes open and Murphy steps in.
How's he doing?
Same. Any luck?
No. I'll try again later. A beat as they look on at Greer.
Murphy and Epps sit at the galley table. Epps reads the l book Murphy found in the radio room.
(reading it)
They're dead in the water that  morning. Four hours later the  captain's relieved of his command.   And that evening they issue a general  SOS.
Possibly false. Hence the IMA record  of being lost at sea. I don't think  mutiny's out of the question here.
(taking a seat)
On a passenger ship in 1953?
If they knew what they were carrying.
You're saying they mutinied for the  gold?
If they were close enough to shore,  they probably figured they could get  away in the lifeboats.
Only something must've gone wrong.
Yeah, way wrong. A beat as they consider it.
So. I got a question. Just from a,  you know, purely technical standpoint.  We call the Coastguard.  Coastguard  shows up. What exactly is the plan?
How do you mean?
Well, they're gonna be asking a lot  of questions. About us. About those  bodies. About the gold. Seems like  we oughta be prepared is all.
I guess the best strategy's just to  tell them the truth.
Yeah, well. The truth is one thing.   When there's more than a few hundred  million dollars involved, that's a  whole new deal.
What do you propose?
For starters, getting that gold off  the ship. What they don't know about  isn't gonna bother them. A beat as Murphy holds there.
There's no way we're gonna hide a  few thousand pounds of gold from the  Coastguard here. Besides, it'll be  safer where it is.
With all due respect, skipper. (a beat)
Part of that up there's mine. I'd  kinda like to have a little say in  what happens to it. A beat as Murphy looks on.

Tell you what, Dodge. Once we get  back to shore, you can do whatever  you want with your share. But until  then, the gold stays right where it  is. Dodge holds there. He looks to Epps a beat, takes a drink coffee.
The sun comes up over a spectacular cloud bank as the Arc Warrior drifts alongside the Chimera.
Murphy crosses to the deck house, climbs the stairs.

Murphy opens the door, stopping dead in his tracks. A bea He steps forward, crossing to the corner. The radio set lies before him, dented in and completely  demolished, as if someone had taken a bat to it.
Dodge works on one of the turbines when he is grabbed fro behind and shoved into the wall. Murphy holds him fast.
Just what the hell do you think you're  doing?!
I don't know what you're talking  about?
I think you know.
Maybe you can tell me then. Murphy shoves him hard into the wall.
The radio!
(not having a clue)
The radio. Oh, yeah, the radio. Murphy tightens his grip.
Take it easy, willya? What about the  radio?!
You smashed it!
What?!
Don't lie to me!
What the fuck -- ?
You didn't want us calling anybody.   Too liable to ruin your big payday.
I didn't touch the fucking radio. Murphy tightens his grip still more.
I didn't touch the fucking radio! (a beat)
Ever occur to you there's somebody  else on that boat, skipper?
Conveniently enough for you.
Look, I didn't touch it. Alright? Murphy holds there a beat longer. He shoves Dodge back le him go.
Jesus. Dodge checks his throat as Murphy looks on.
Murphy. They turn to see Epps in the hatchway.
It's Greer.
Greer stands at the galley sink finishing off the last of jug of water as Murphy and the others step in. He turns t see them.
Never been more thirsty in my life.
Drink up then. Greer smiles, raising the jug to drink as the others take seat, looking on at him.
How're you feeling?
Lost my sea legs.
Any dizziness?
No.
Headache, nausea, lights?
Lights?
Sudden flashes of light.
I feel fine.
What day is it?
I don't know. Tuesday?
Wrong. It's Friday.
Try Wednesday.
Right. Wednesday. A beat as they all hold there. Greer takes a seat.
What happened?
You don't remember?
Last thing I remember I was aboard  the Chimera. Down somewhere in there  scavenging around.
You've been out for about a day.
Say what?
Dodge found you out cold in one of  the cabins. Greer only holds there.
Oh, man.
We heard you scream. Any idea what  you might've seen?
I wish I could tell you. I'd be real  interested to know myself. Another beat as they hold there, as Greer takes another d of water.
The ah... the radio's out.
What?
Somebody took it out of commission  last night. A beat as they all hold there.
Smashed it up pretty bad.
But, who -- ?
The skipper seems to think I did it.  That I'm more interested in that  gold than my own safety or the safety  of my fellow shipmates. A beat as they hold there, as Murphy looks back.
Did you?
Hell no. You think I'm crazy? Another beat as they hold there.

Regardless of how it happened, there  isn't much of a chance to fix it.  The odds of another vessel in range  of the walkie-talkies are almost  astronomical. So, as of today, we're  pretty much on our own out here.
Epps and Murphy, carrying the shotgun, make their way in ship.
Greer stops before a mirror to see himself. He finds an  aspirin bottle, goes to open it. And as he does so, he se that his hand is shaking uncontrollably.

Dodge works over the turbine. He stops, holding there. He looks on at the plugs and wires and hoses. A beat. He begins pulling out the hoses and wires, grabbing at th yanking them loose, breaking them off.
The chassis comes off an old radio to reveal a dusty  assortment of tubes and condensers. Murphy looks on at it

A tattered, bound book lies in the refuse of a forgotten  corner. Epps picks it up. The cover has been ripped off a the pages are torn. But, as she looks through it, she see that it is the ship's log.
Murphy. Murphy steps over as she pages through the log book to th very end. The last pages have been ripped out.
Looks like part of the general log. Epps points to a page that has been incompletely ripped o
"The crew have gone mad with greed  and fight among themselves like wild  dogs over fresh kill."
February first.
The same day she supposedly went  down.
Must not've been the captain's entry.  He was probably out of the picture  by then. Epps continues to read.
"Their lacking diligence has  undoubtedly caused the collision.   Distress calls have been made."
Collision? With what?
The page's missing. Then their SOS  was real.
But where's the damage?
Maybe the other ship took the worst  of it.
If it was a ship she hit. A beat as they hold there, when his radio CRACKLES TO LIF
Dodge to Murphy! Murphy reaches down for his radio.
(to radio)
Yeah.
You better get down here right now!   We're taking water! Big time!

Murphy and Epps jump from the deck crane as the tug is  starting to list to one side. He crosses to the deck hous and the open engine room hatch to see that it is rapidly  filling with seawater as Greer and Dodge scramble to set pump hose over the DIN OF THE PUMPS.
What the hell happened!
Turbine chamber on number two must've  blown! Took out part of the hull!
We're not gonna be able to pump it!
Alright. Everybody grab your gear!   This' is where we get off!

The tug is listing radically to the side, its deck awash  with seawater, as Epps, Greer, and Murphy scramble with t gear to the crane. Water is starting to pour out of the deckhouse hatch as t towering framework rising over the pilothouse stabs  precariously at the bow of the Chimera. Murphy stops to shout back at the deckhouse.
Dodge!
Water is starting to pour in as the entire cabin lurches one side. Dodge wades through toward the door.
Epps pulls herself up onto the deck, Greer following behi then Murphy. Dodge can be seen stepping from the deckhouse on the tug, which now lists at a near 45 degree angle.

Dodge stumbles toward the bow, slipping on the wet deck. goes down, sliding into the water that washes over the  starboard rail. He pulls himself up, using a cleat to push off. A deck lo opens and the contents tumble around him. He struggles to pull himself up to the base of the pilothouse. He climbs and edges his way toward the bow.
Epps, Greer and Murphy look on as Dodge climbs up on the  skewed deck crane.
The tug is slowly lurching over as Dodge climbs the crane the top of which is sweeping away from the Chimera. Below, the decks of the tug are swept with seawater as it sinks lower and lower.
They look on as Dodge climbs toward them, the sinking tug pulling Dodge and the crane away from the ship. Greer pulls back a line, tying it into the deck railing.

As Dodge makes his way up, he's forced to climb onto the  other side of the crane to keep from dangling over the wa Above, Greer casts a line. It falls near, but out of reac as the swell of the water starts to swing the crane to an fro.  Dodge reaches out for the line again, his hand comi close but not close enough. The swell brings the crane toward the boat one last time Dodge reaches out, his fingers just coming to the line,  coaxing it into his grasp. He pulls it back and hangs on, the crane sways back with the foundering boat. The crane falls away from Dodge, leaving him hanging in s by the line from the bow of the Chimera.

Murphy, Greer and Epps look on as Dodge hangs over the wa and the tug as its stern slowly sinks beneath the waves. Dodge climbs the line toward the bow railing as the tug r still further to port, the pilothouse dipping into the se slipping lower and lower.

As he pulls himself upward, coming to the bottom of the r well on the Chimera where Murphy reaches out, just short Dodge's hand. A SCREECHING SOUNDS and they turn to see the twin tow cab coming taught against the hull in the anchor alley's of t Chimera as the sinking tug pulls them tight. With a CONCUSSIVE STRIKE, one cable is freed, snapping ag the Chimera's hull like a giant steel guitar string.  It  starts sliding along the hull as the tug drifts, pulling cable with it, toward Dodge as he dangles in mid air. Dodge pulls himself up, reaching for Murphy, but still sh A LOUD HISSING SOUNDS and Dodge turns to see misty air  escaping from ports and deck vents as the encroaching wat forces it out of the tug below decks. The tow cable LOUDLY SCRAPES THE HULL in a shower of rust as Dodge struggles to pull himself up. Murphy reaches out as Dodge extends as far as he can, the hands barely reaching. The tow cable is a mere few feet away and closing, ready scrape Dodge into the water or smear him across the hull  like a bug on a windshield, when Dodge pulls himself up w everything he's got and Murphy grabs his hand. Murphy pulls, lifting Dodge, as Greer grabs Dodge's other hand and they pull him up, the tow cable sweeping by with SICKENING GRINDING SOUND OF HEAVY STEEL AGAINST STEEL. Dodge turns to see the bow of the tug dip below the surfa slowly going under until disappearing with a last exhalat of misty air. The pilothouse is next to go, the last of i slipping into the frothing water, then the crane, finally disappearing altogether into the depths. A long beat as they hold there in the sudden silence, pha bubbles rising to the surface where the tug once stood.
A boot punches through a rotten wood hull.
That just about says it all. Greer stands at the bow of a lifeboat suspended from haly above the deck.
Rotten stem to stern. Guess you  couldn't expect much else. Greer jumps down as Murphy, Dodge, and Epps look on.
We ain't exactly in what you'd call  your high traffic neighborhood either.
The coast guard has our last position.  They'll send somebody out soon enough.  A ship this size you can't exactly  miss.
It's a good bet they'll be asking a  lot of questions when they get here  too.
Let 'em ask. This ship's legally  ours now.
When they find out what it's carrying,  they may not be so interested in  what's legal.
Maybe you shoulda thought a that  before you scuttled our boat. Dodge turns to see Greer. A beat.
The turbine blew.
Lemme see, was that before or after  the oil fire? A beat. Dodge takes a swing at Greer.
(grabbing Dodge)
Easy, easy. Murphy holds on to Dodge as he will have none of it.
Gettin' a little hot under the collar,  I'd say.
Shut up.
Must be a little too the truth, eh  Dodge? Dodge jumps forward again, but Murphy hangs on.
I said, shut the hell up. Murphy shoves Dodge back.
Both of you. I don't want to hear it  again. A beat as Greer and Murphy hold there.
So just stow it. You understand? (a beat)
We don't need this right now.
A fire burns in an oil drum as Epps, Murphy, Dodge and Gr sit around it in silence.
Epps steps in. She shines her light on the room. It is ex as it was left. She crosses to the bed, shining her light under it. She sits down, trying it.
Dodge moves in the darkness, coming to the corner where t stacked gold ingots rest. He looks on at them.
You shouldn't be down here alone. Dodge turns to see Murphy standing there.
Just wanted to check on our little  baby. A beat as they look on at the gold.
That oughta buy a man pretty much  anything he wants.
If money can buy what he wants.
I don't figure there's much I want  money can't buy.
Then you're a lucky man. Murphy tosses the shotgun to Dodge, who catches it.
We'll stand the watch on deck tonight.  You're up first.
Right. Murphy holds there a beat longer, then turns to go, as Do looks after him.
A grey chop gently rocks the Chimera, smoke rising from t top deck.
Greer and Dodge tend the flames of three fire barrels, ad broken up furniture to create heavy signal smoke.
Murphy moves through the pantry area with a pillow case,  scavenging for food.
Epps scavenges for food in the semi-darkness of the large open galley, when a MOVEMENT CAN BE HEARD SOMEWHERE BEYON THE ENTRY separating the galley from the outer passageway
