Murphy? No one answers. She looks off across the stillness of the galley. Nothing.
Epps steps into the passageway. Directly across is the en to the swimming pool. She walks on.

Epps steps in. Light falls in from the dirty port holes a the ceiling, every movement echoing off the hard tile wal She holds there a beat, then turns to go when she sees a  GIRL of about 16 facing her on the other side of the pool Epps holds there, as the girl only looks back. She is  porcelain white, flaxen hair drawn behind her head, her  clothing hanging loosely from a frail body.
You must leave. A beat as Epps stands there.
(finally)
Who are you? From this distance and in the light it is hard to fully  discern the girl's features.
There's great evil here, more than  you can know. Leave now or you may  never leave.

But -- A HATCH CLOSES SOMEWHERE IN THE SHIP. Epps turns to look. When she turns back the girl is gone. A quiet "TICK" SOUN ECHOES in the pool. She looks down to see that the pool i now very, very deep, like a mine shaft falling away into depths. And, as she stands there, dark water is quickly r up from the bottom. She steps back as the water gradually fills the pool to t top. It is very dark and the bottom is indiscernible, whe the water begins to churn, as from bubbles of air reachin the surface. Epps steps closer, looking on as a faint red glow can be seen deep in the water below the churning bub As she watches, the red glow grows in intensity. The glow spreads, illuminating a broad area until it becomes clear that the water is not water at all but blood. And, as the light grows still brighter, a figure is  illuminated, well below the surface as it seems to rise u Epps looks on as the figure rises higher into the light. is a MAN, fighting desperately to reach the surface. The  bubbles that rise up are produced from his silent screams Epps starts forward, but another figure rises to the same point, a WOMAN, also struggling. Another MAN floats up, t another, and another, people floating up, fighting desper to reach the surface, unable to do so, drowning in blood.

My God.... Epps reaches out over the edge, plunging her hand into th blood, reaching for the man's hand, but they are too far  apart. She struggles desperately as the man fights to get to the surface. The others are fighting for the surface too, as Epps reac out, near tears, helpless to do anything.
No!! Everything suddenly stops. A beat as Epps only holds ther The blood is gone, as are the people. The pool is back to its normal state as though nothing had happened, Epps loo on in disbelief.
You okay? Epps looks up to see Murphy standing at the door.
Yeah. (looking back to the  pool)
Yeah, fine. A beat as she holds there, looking on at the pool.
Greer, Murphy, Dodge, and Epps sit on deck around the fir
You'd think on a ship this size  there'd be something left to eat.
After fifty years there ain't nothin'  left but shoe leather.
Tomorrow we'll see if we can't find  some line and tackle. Use some of  those bodies below decks for bait.
There's a charming thought.
We can always start shooting birds. Epps coaxes a hit out of her last cigarette.
What say, Epps? You up for some  roasted albatross?
(snuffing it out)
Why not?

The SOUND OF SOMEONE BREATHING HARD CAN BE HEARD in the d room. As the CAMERA SLOWLY MOVES INTO THE ROOM, we see th it is Greer, lying on the bed. His body is tense and his  arms arch rigidly toward his chest. His jaw is clenched a he expels harsh, guttural utterances, experiencing someth between a night terror and a seizure.
Sheets of rain come down on the deck in the grey light of morning. Murphy stands on the bridge, looking off at it c down when Greer steps in.
Looks like we're in a strong current. (closing the door)
Must be making almost five knots  full on ass backwards. Greer crosses to the window, stepping up.
Nasty little swell outa the north  west too. Murphy nods as he looks out.
Let's just hope somebody sees us  first out here.

A file drawer comes open, revealing ticket receipts. Epps looks on at it. The receipts are labeled "FULL FARE  PASSAGES" and are divided by first, second, and third cla She goes through them, coming to a section that says

She pulls out the folder, laying it on the counter, openi it. The first page is a receipt for a single passage to  Halifax for a Tatterly, Stephen age: 14. She pulls it bac to reveal another, Wilson, Harold age: 4. Another, Vitti, Angela age: 17. She pages through the stack, looking at the ages: 3, 15, 11, 1, until coming across a 9. She looks to the name, Kl David, a boy. She continues paging through the receipts c to another 9. She stops, looking to the name, Nichols,  Katherine age: 16. A girl. She looks to the cabin assignm "400." She notes that it is the same cabin where Greer wa found, when a REVERBERANT CONCUSSION SOUNDS THROUGH THE S
Dodge runs to the side to see a 15 feet wide by 40 feet t steel and concrete mid-ocean buoy bounce off the transom the ship drifts into it.
They come to the side at the wheelhouse, seeing the brigh orange letters "NOAA" emblazoned on the buoy's float pod the ship drifts by.
It's a Noaa buoy.
A what?
Government weather. It's got a  transmitter aboard.
Dodge quickly ties a loop in a coil of docking line as Gr Epps, and Murphy look on at the approaching buoy.
Let's go, let's go, let's go. Dodge finishes as Epps ties the other end off to a cleat.
As it drifts along the side of the Chimera. Murphy drops line down, the buoy bouncing on the swell.
Murphy pulls the loop up as the buoy nears, aiming to hoo it on its wind gauge.
The buoy approaches, rising and falling with the swell.
Murphy corrects.
Higher. You're gonna miss it. Murphy holds the loop steady.
The loop is too low. It's going to miss the mark as the b drifts toward it, when the swell drops and the buoy goes  down.
Murphy yanks on the line.
And the loop catches on the wind gauge.
As the line goes taught he pulls his hands away just in t the line snapping hard against the rail. Below, the buoy  heels over as it's pulled.
It drops with the swell, the line stretching, then swingi the giant concrete buoy float into the side of the hull w a huge BOOMING CLANG.
The line is smoking with the friction, the steel railing  bowing a little with the weight as they look on.
We're still drifting.
The mooring hasn't come taught.
It's not gonna hold us.
Doesn't matter.

As the buoy falls again with a swell and slams into the s of the ship. The water returns, lifting it high. The ship is dragging it back and it begins to rise up as mooring comes taught. The line rises with it and soon the buoy is at a steep angle as it comes out of the water.
The buoy is held fast between the docking line and its ow mooring.
The buoy rises fully from the water, all three tons of it and as it does, the wind gauge's steel mount begins to be
As they watch the buoy suspended over the water between t creaking docking line and its own underwater mooring cabl
No fucking way.
The gauge mount snaps and the docking line flails free,  sending the buoy hurtling back into the water in a curtai of spray, whipping wildly from side to side.
The buoy swings back and forth as it rights itself, risin on a swell, passing beyond the bow of the Chimera.
Damn it. They look on in silence, the buoy slowly receding as the  ship drifts away.
Murphy stands watch by the fire as Epps joins him.
Hey.
Hey.
Couldn't sleep.
Wish I could say the same. They watch the fire in silence for a moment.
What do you think happened on this  boat?
I guess that's the sixty four thousand  dollar question, isn't it?
The what?
Never mind. Before your time. (a beat)

I think at least some of the crew  went a little nuts. The usual stuff  that happens when people stumble on  a fortune. Equal parts greed and  paranoia, usually resulting in  homicide. What happened after that  is anybody's guess. But, judging by  our Greek friends down below, it  doesn't look like the last time.
Are we smart enough to avoid that?
I don't know, are we? A beat as she looks back at him. She looks back to the fi watching it.
When you found me yesterday, at the  pool. I'd seen... something.  Someone.
Not our mystery guest again.
No. Someone else. A girl. (hesitating, a beat)
I'm not sure she was... real. She looks up to Murphy.
Not real? A beat as she only looks back.
What, like some kind of ghost?
I don't know what else you'd call  her. One second she was there, the  next she was gone. Another beat as he looks on at her.
And I had a kind of hallucination. (a beat)
There were others. I saw them in the  pool. Drowning. A beat as Murphy looks back, as she sees him.
Maybe hallucination is the wrong  word. It was more than that. As though  they were showing me.
Showing you what?
What happened.
Maybe it was one of them did the  handy work on those Greeks.
No. I think they are, were, just  passengers. Innocent victims.
Victims of what?
Something bad happened here, Murphy.
That much I think we've already  established.
More than just a mutiny. More than  just the gold. A beat as he holds there.
She said the ship was evil. That we  had to leave right away. That if we  didn't, we might never leave.
What's that supposed to mean?
I don't know. A beat as she looks back.
Why you? How come the rest of us  haven't seen these people?
Just lucky I guess. Another beat as he holds on her.
Well. Getting off this ship's exactly  what we're trying to do.  Short of  that, I don't know what else to tell  you. She only looks back at him, then into the fire.
Do me a favor and wake up Dodge.   He's next on. She starts to get up.
And Epps? She stands, looking back at him.
You can tell the others about this.   But, for my money, I think it's best  you keep it to yourself. She holds there a beat longer, then turns, walking off.
Epps comes to the 2nd officer's door, knocks.
Dodge. (no answer, knocking  again)
Dodge.
(finally, from inside)
What?
Get up.
Yeah, yeah.
Epps sits down on the bed. She lies back, not sleepy. A b as she holds there in the darkness.
Murphy still sits by the fire as Dodge groggily approache from the officers quarters, carrying a blanket and a jug water.
You're late.
Sorry.
(handing him the  shotgun)
Don't fall asleep.
(laying out his blanket)
Right.

Greer lies asleep on the bed. But his sleep is fitful,  increasingly agitated, tormented. It is as if he tries to speak, but cannot. As THE CAMERA PUSHES SLOWLY IN, his wo are forced and garbled, speaking in the same nonsensical  language he spoke earlier, when he wakes with a start.
Dodge dozes, cradling the shotgun in his arms, when MUSIC CAN BE HEARD VERY DISTANTLY. Dodge wakes. It is "Daisy"  playing on a music box somewhere in the ship.
Dodge moves along as the MUSIC BOX DISTANTLY CONTINUES.

Dodge moves cautiously down the stairway into another  passageway. He approaches from the other end. He passes the open door of stateroom after stateroom. The MUSIC BOX IS CLOSER HER It stops. He holds there in the darkness. He turns, shining his lig back down the passageway. A beat. It is silent, when the  CHANNEL OF HIS RADIO OPENS WITH A SHORT BURST. He raises his radio. But no one says anything, the CHANNE REMAINING OPEN, a discernible presence on the other end.
Dodge.
SLOWLY MOVING TOWARD DODGE as he can be seen from the oth end of the passageway.
He gets no response, then presses the talk button.
This is Dodge. Over. He is answered by silence, the CHANNEL REMAINING OPEN, WH

head_text.subj: THE GRAVELLY DISTORTED VOICE THAT MURPHY HEARD COMES BACK

text: "Cock-a-doodle-doo," said the rooster  to the crow. "Where are you now? I  know but won't say so." Dodge hits the talk button.
Who is this? The RADIO CHANNEL OPENS, but only silence comes back.
Identify yourself, motherfucker!
SLOWLY MOVING TOWARD DODGE as he can be seen from the far end of the passageway.
Only silence returns on the radio as Dodge holds there, t
Penny whistle toy. Penny whistle  toy. THE CAMERA PUSHES SLOWLY IN ON DODGE as he listens.

Penny whistle toy. Penny whistle toy -- . Dodge senses something behind him. He turns, and before h can draw a breath to shout, SOMETHING HEAVY SLAMS INTO HI IN THE DARKNESS, his flashlight tumbling away in a squigg of light.
As the shotgun clatters to the deck, the muzzle resting i frame as the radio falls a few feet away. A beat. The sho muzzle slides out of frame as some unseen person or thing pulls it away.
A grey overcast stretches to the horizon.
Murphy comes out onto the deck. Dodge is nowhere to be se
Dodge?
Epps shines her light on something.
Check it out. Greer raises his light to reveal rows of canned goods. Th are industrial sized cans, from the 1950s. Greer takes on
I don't even want to know what that's  gonna taste like now.
Better than starving to death. Epps' radio CRACKLES AWAKE.
Murphy to Epps.
(raising the radio)
Epps, over.
Either of you seen Dodge? She looks to Greer who shakes his head.
Nope.
He's not on deck and I can't raise  him on the radio.
Dodge's stuff is laid out under the shelter of a vent duc as Greer, Epps, and Murphy stand over it. A blanket, a pi and a plastic jug of water are all that remain.
He took the shotgun and a light.
Must've heard something below deck  and went down to check it out. A beat as they hold there.
Alright. We stay together. Nobody  goes any further than earshot.
Greer and Epps move along as Murphy raises his radio.
(into radio)
Murphy to Dodge. Murphy to Dodge.   Over.
Dodge's radio lies in the detritus of the ship as Murphy' voice can be heard on it.
Murphy to Dodge. Do you copy? Over.
Epps moves cautiously along in the darkness.
Epps? You there?
Right here.
As he moves along as well, eyes open.
Greer?
As Greer moves along too.
Yeah, yeah.
Epps jumps down, shining her light over machinery and acr bulkheads when a WHISPERING CAN BE HEARD somewhere. She h there, listening. It is echoey, distant.
Murphy? No response as Epps holds there. The WHISPERING SOUNDS AG far off, unintelligible. It stops. She moves on, shinning her light.

Epps moves along in the darkness, holding the flashlight  before her, when the WHISPERING SOUNDS AGAIN. Epps stops, holding there in the silence. She reaches for her radio. The WHISPERING SOUNDS AGAIN. Epps turns to pin it, coming from somewhere in the cavernous space.

Epps passes under a catwalk. She moves on, passing a row standpipes. Epps stops, listening. Somewhere, the WHISPER CAN BE HEARD, then stops. It is absolutely silent. In the darkness behind her, the  GIRL (KATIE) PULLS BACK INTO THE SHADOWS. Epps holds there a beat, then turns, running into Greer w a start.
Sorry. Didn't mean to scare you. She holds there a beat, looking around.
You okay?
Yeah. Fine. I just thought I heard  something is all.
What?

Nothing. Let's get outa here. They start to leave, when Epps notices something. She sto Beyond the standpipes, a faint glow can be seen in the  darkness. Epps steps forward, crossing to it. Greer follo
As Epps approaches, Greer behind her. The light is dim an low to the deck. She stops.

As Epps starts toward it again. She and Greer come up to stopping there. She kneels, the dim glow shining on her. reaches out toward it, pulling back Dodge's flashlight, s on. She turns it off, standing. She shines her light into the darkness and starts off, Greer following.

Epps and Greer move along, shining their lights as they g when something catches in the beam of Epps' flashlight. It is Dodge's radio. They stop over it. Epps picks it up, inspecting it. She looks to Greer, when a single dark spo appears on Epps' cheek. It begins to run, a crimson tear. She raises her hand to touch it, inspecting her finger to see that it is blood. She looks to Greer. They both look up to see, hanging  suspended above them, Dodge's face staring back down at t from the darkness. He has been imperfectly impaled, the sharp point of a hig pressure steam pipe protruding from his neck, head hangin limp beside it.
Greer and Murphy lower Dodge's body on a rope as Epps gui it to the deck. They stand looking on at it a moment.
Can't find the shotgun.
So whoever did this now has our  shotgun.
Doesn't look like it much matters.
What do we do with him?
Leave him till we can get some help. (a beat)
From now on, nobody comes down here.
What about the gold?
Leave it.
Now hold up just a minute. Let's be  reasonable here.
You think whoever did this is  reasonable?
All I'm saying is that gold's worth  a lot more to us now than it ever  was.
I can't believe you. Dodge's dead  and all you can think about is cashing  in your share.
I didn't sign up to go home empty  handed. And I sure ain't gonna roll  over for the freaky motherfucker did  this.
Nobody's going anywhere with that  gold now. Anybody tries to board,  we'll know about it. (a beat)
You can do what you want, Greer.   But neither of us is gonna risk saving  your ass down here if it comes to  that.
Fine with me.

Epps enters the dim passageway from the bright daylight. moves down the passage, coming finally to the stateroom w Greer was found, room 400. She holds there a beat, then reaches for the door, hesita She opens it.

The door comes open and Epps steps in. It is dark, though spacious. It is divided into two rooms. Beyond the sittin room in the front, is a bedroom. Epps steps in. A dressing table sits against the far wall A large bed is unmade. Suitcases lie open on stands at th foot of the bed, still half full as if they were in the  process of being unpacked. From one, she pulls back a woman's gown, a blouse. The ot contains shirts, trousers, socks, and underwear. Across the room a smaller suitcase can be seen lying open an Ottoman in the corner. Epps crosses to it. She finds a few shirts, and a red print dress, some books. She takes of the books, opening it. Inscribed on the inside of the cover is: "This book belon to:" and then written in by hand: "Katie Nichols." A page is marked with a purple ribbon. She opens it to se children's poem "The Rooster and the Crow" and a drawing a rooster and a crow and a stanza of a poem: "'Cock-a-doo doo,' said the rooster to the crow. 'Where are you now? I know, but won't say so.'" She puts it down. A tin penny  whistle sits on the table. She picks it up, examining it. She opens a small picture book, thumbing through to see p of a family, a young mother and father at the beach, the  mother and a girl of about 9 years, the girl and an older girl of about 16, the girl she saw at the swimming pool,  KATIE. Epps holds on this picture, when A MUSIC BOX SOUND She looks up to the dressing table. On it a music box slo plays "Daisy."

Epps crosses to it, looking on at the music box as it slo winds down, then finally stops. A beat. She picks it up,  looking at it, when she looks up to see Greer standing th A beat. The dirty white light falling into the room through the  windows falls on him as he looks off at something we cann see. His expression is empty, hollow.
Greer? He does not hear her as he stands there. She approaches,  stepping up.

You okay? Another beat, as he looks off, into the light, when he sl turns to see her. A long beat as she looks back. He holds there, the same e look about him, when he grabs her by the throat and squee hard. She is stunned, breathless, but raises her hands to grip wrists, fighting him.
Greer! His grip tightens. He is much stronger and her efforts ma little difference.
Let go! She hangs on, starting to choke. She drops one hand, sear with it.

Oragishlaoomnudrasadrafantoshviska  getofedobrodijotosiantosg. He speaks nonsense, his face distorted in an ugly grimace eyes bulging as Epps fumbles over the table, a tray of gl and silver crashing to the floor as he pushes her back, s choking her. He backs her to the wall, pushing in, closing her windpip the rest of the way. Her hand searches behind her, knocking over a small vase, basket, some books. It comes to a brass desk lamp. It fal a little out of reach. She is going to black out any second, as Greer strangles  her. Her hand comes to the desk lamp, grabbing it. She raises the lamp, swinging with all her might, connect with Greer's head. He stumbles back, a gash laid into his face, as Epps suck in air, gagging and coughing, her neck purple with finger marks.  She fumbles her radio up.
(into radio)

Murphy! I'm on C deck, cabin 400!   Get down here now!! Blood is running down his face as Greer comes for her aga She throws down the radio. A bed stands between them. She feints right, then left. H dazed and has blood in his eyes. She manages to slip by, he dives, taking her down. He drags her back along the floor, spinning her around. H raises a fist to ram into her face when WHAM! Epps has shoved the butt of her flashlight into his crotc and he comes up SCREAMING. He grabs her face, striking he with his other hand. She swings the flashlight again and cracks him across the head. He swings yet again and connects, knocking her acro the floor. She lies in a heap as Greer climbs to his feet, enraged a bleeding. He unbuckles his belt as he approaches, pulling it from h waist to do God knows what. Epps looks around to see him approaching. And we see that she has unhinged her gill knife. As his foot steps near, she lets go and drives the knife  with all her might into his boot, plunging the blade thro his foot and into the floor. He SCREAMS. After a moment he stops, looks to her. He is a bloody,  wretched, enraged mess. He starts toward her as Murphy ap in the doorway. Just as Greer is upon her, Murphy blind sides Greer from  behind at full speed, knocking him down. Greer and Murphy struggle as Epps climbs unsteadily to he feet. She staggers to them and raises the flashlight over Greer, bringing it down on his head.
Epps and Murphy carry Greer's unconscious body.
Greer tumbles down a sand bank in an empty aquarium. He s at the bottom, now starting to come to.
Murphy slams the door shut as Epps looks on. She puts a s pipe across the hatch lever so that it cannot be opened.

Greer sits in the tank, visible through a large piece of  armored aquarium glass, amidst the fake coral. He sits in the sand hugging his legs to his chest, bobbing slightly he speaks in his nonsensical language.
Must've been him all along. Murphy and Epps look on from the outside in the promenade
Smashed the radio. Scuttled the boat.  Killed Dodge. Would've killed you.  He's off his nut, no doubt there. They watch him in silence a moment as Greer mutters and b
What do you think?
Could be a stroke. Who knows? (a beat)
The general log said the crew were  fighting among themselves. "Like  wild dogs."
Over the gold.
Maybe it was more than that. Greer gets up, comes to the window, looking out at them. presses his face to the glass.
They went crazy.
Crazy with greed. Not crazy. Not  like him. A beat as Epps looks off. In the window Greer drags his  hideously distorted face over the glass, the blood from h wounds smearing in broad red streaks.
A partial hull of a rotting life boat falls into frame. E and Murphy stand over it.
We lash a few of these together it  might get us far enough into the  shipping lanes to be rescued. A beat as they look on at the rotting hull.
Hard to say which is worse, staying  here or taking our chances in open  water.
If the weather holds it might not be  so bad.
It's not the weather I'm worried  about. The wrong current could drag  us as far as the Aleutians before we  come across another boat.
Epps and Murphy work to lash parts of the rotting boats i a single usable raft.
Greer lies asleep on the sand bottom of the tank, the whi light from the skylight falling on him from above.
Epps has found a reel of wire and some metal braces, maki her way into the darkness, when her radio CRACKLES TO LIF The channel remains silent a moment, then closes. She sto raises the radio.
(holding down talk  button)
Murphy? She waits, holding there as only silence comes back.
Murphy, this is Epps. Do you copy? Again, only silence comes back until, after a moment, the channel opens again. No one speaks, though there is a pal presence on the other end.
(raising the radio)
Who is this? The channel opens again, only silence returning. The soun of the MUSIC BOX CAN BE HEARD, "DAISY" COMING BACK OVER T RADIO.

Epps walks along in the darkness AS THE MUSIC BOX CONTINU TO PLAY OVER THE RADIO. She comes to the end of the corri stopping there. At the other end the light falls from the door at room 40 The MUSIC FROM THE RADIO STOPS, leaving in its absence th

head_text.subj: MUSIC AS IT CAN BE HEARD COMING FROM THE ROOM AT THE END

text: Epps approaches the other end, from where the MUSIC EMANA coming to a stop at room 400. A beat as she holds there.

Epps steps in as THE MUSIC BOX PLAYS IN THE OTHER ROOM. The sitting room is dark as she holds there. After a mome she continues on, coming to the bedroom. Epps steps in. Across the room the MUSIC BOX IS PLAYING. She crosses, coming to it as it continues, when her radio CRACKLES TO LIFE. The channel remains silent a moment, th

"Cock-a-doodle-doo, said the rooster  to the crow. Where are you now? I  know but won't say so." She holds there a beat, then crosses to the table to find the book of nursery rhymes. She opens it to the nursery r "The Rooster and the Crow," seeing the same words on the  page, when the radio CRACKLES AGAIN.

Penny whistle toy. Penny whistle  toy. Penny whistle toy. Penny whistle  toy. On the table is the penny whistle she saw earlier. She ta it, holding on it a moment. She raises it and THE CAMERA  SLOWLY PUSHES IN as she puts it to her lips and lightly b a C-SHARP WHICH BECOMES A C-SHARP FROM A PENNY WHISTLE ac the room.

"Cock-a-doodle-doo, said the rooster  to the crow. Where are you now? I  know but won't say so." On the other side of the room, the younger girl from the  photo plays the penny whistle. She is sitting on the floo with the MOTHER who reads from the book we saw earlier.
"Cock-a-doodle-doo, said the rooster  to the crow. Where are you now? I  know but won't say so." Cassandra,  if you insist on playing that while  I read I'll just stop right now.

Sorry. The room is warm with light, restored to its original  condition some fifty years ago as Epps stands there, unse no longer holding the whistle. A man, the FATHER from the photos, steps from the bathroo wearing a new coat.
What do you think?
He certainly did shorten it, didn't  he?
I thought this was all the rage.
Maybe last year. Katie joins them from the outer room.
What about this year?
It's not your color anyway.
I like it, daddy.
Well thank you!
Daddy, how much longer before we  start moving again?
They're working on the engines, honey.  As soon as they fix them we'll be on  our way.

Epps steps from room 400 into the passageway. It is lit w sconces running its length and the elegant furnishings an objets d'art stretching to the far end are all in their  original condition. DISTANT MUSIC FROM THE BALLROOM CAN B HEARD as Epps stands there. She moves along.
Epps walks in the passageway. Doors are open and she look in to see people doing various things, some packing and  putting their things in order.

Epps walks down the passage, rounding the corner to see t STEWARDS fighting with a fourth MAN in a tuxedo. They lif him up and carry him off down the stairs as he shouts and protests. She moves on, through a pair of double doors, i

Epps moves through the now lighted storage area off the  galley. A group of CREWMEN stand around at the other end  and, as Epps nears, she sees that four figures can be see among them. They are four men, OFFICERS, swaying gently f the ship's movement as they hang from ropes around their  neck, dead. Epps keeps moving, through doors at the other end.

A commotion can be heard at the other end of the passagew as Epps keeps moving. A WOMAN SCREAMS, and is cut off whe door slams shut. The DISTANT MUSIC HAS BEEN REPLACED WITH INDISCERNIBLE  SHOUTING, as of someone commandeering the microphone some As she walks, she passes an open door where several CREWM fight over a steamer trunk, which breaks open, scattering the contents.

Epps walks along, coming to another door where a dead man and woman are laying in the middle of the room as a STEWA takes money from a wallet. The steward looks up, reaches  over and slams the door shut. She continues on. Another door stands open as she comes to it, back at room 400. She stops. A REPETITIVE SOUND CAN BE HEARD, coming f inside.

Epps steps in as the SOUND CONTINUES. She crosses the sit room, coming to the doorway of the bedroom to find severa MUTINEERS, some in stewards attire, others wearing ships  officers caps, obviously taken from their rightful owners The repetitive sound comes from here, bed springs. And, f between the men, a woman's bare legs hang over the end of the bed as a pair of man's legs in boots lie between them the bed rocking, the others looking on. Epps turns to see the father. He is on his knees, hands t behind his back as he is forced to watch from the foot of the bed.

a geometric pattern of a lotus on the Persian carpet at h feet. When she looks up again she sees what the father se The mutineer finishes, climbing off the woman. Another of the men pulls her up to reveal that she is no woman at al but Katie. The mother and sister lie in a bloody heap near-by as one the other mutineers steps up to Epps.

You like that, daddy? I'll show you  something else now. The mutineer steps back to the bed. He sits Katie down so that she faces us on the end of the bed. He raises an axe over her, bringing it down as the world becomes a whirlin blur --
The CAMERA STOPS ON KATIE standing on the other side of t room, now empty of people, returned to its shabby, abando state.
It isn't real. Epps looks back at her from the other side of the room wh she stands.

Many bad things have happened here.   But you mustn't allow the evil inside.  I tell you this because you can see  me. The others can't. But you must  leave. You must leave. A LOUD GUNSHOT SOUNDS SOMEWHERE IN THE SHIP. When Epps tu back Katie is gone.
Epps moves quickly along, raising her radio.
Epps to Murphy. Only WHITE NOISE COMES BACK.

Epps to Murphy. Only WHITE NOISE COMES BACK as she rounds the corner out  onto the promenade. At the other end, the aquarium can be seen. As she approaches she sees that the tank is empty. Greer nowhere to be seen and the skylight at the top is broken  out. A GREAT BOOMING SHUDDER rocks the ship. A LOUD SCREECHING METAL follows it.

The ship's hull being scraped at the waterline by a jagge mid-ocean island no bigger than fifty or sixty feet acros The ship has entered a small archipelago of such islands, mine field for a drifting ship.
Epps moves quickly along, coming to the stairway, moving almost running into Murphy on his way down, carrying a ca duffle.
What happened?
We hit land.
What?
We're in an island chain. It's only  a matter of time before we hit another  one.
Greer's gone. He broke out of the  tank.
Epps and Murphy move quickly along, when another HUGE BOO shudders the ship and the SHRIEKING OF METAL follows.
The ship bounces off another of the small, jagged islands it drifts past, buckling the steel plate of the hull  precariously.
Murphy and Epps run toward the other end of the ship. As  they do, something can be seen lying in the middle of the passage some distance down.
Epps and Murphy slow to see that it is a body, lying face down in the passage. They step up. Epps kneels as Murphy looks on. She rolls t body over. It is Greer, dead.
He's been shot. Murphy kneels too, looking on at Greer's lifeless eyes.
Let's get the hell out of here.
Murphy and Epps come up the stairway, crossing to the doo
As Epps and Murphy come out, moving toward the make-do ra
It should be enough to get us to one  of those islands. Gimme a hand,  wouldya? She joins him and they lift it off its stand, taking it t the rail.
Prop it here. We need to pull these  braces off. There's a hammer on the  stand. There. Epps crosses back to the stands.
Epps kneels. No hammer. She pulls back Murphy's canvas du folding back the flap to reveal a shotgun, the shotgun Do had when he died. A beat as she holds there, when Murphy's hand grabs it.
I'll take that. A beat as she looks to Murphy.
It was you. He only looks back at her as she stands there.
You killed them.
It was only a matter of time before  somebody killed somebody. (a beat)

You saw it coming as well as I did.   Dodge had his plans, starting with  scuttling the boat. And Greer too,  except he went nuts. Couldn't take  it, I guess. Could've happened in  the middle of downtown Anchorage.   But did it make him any less  dangerous? I don't think so.
So you killed them?

The way I figure it, it was them or  me. I thought putting Dodge up on  that pipe was a nice touch? Bought a  little time. Made it look like whoever  killed those Greeks was still around.  But it's just us on this ship. Us  and your... spirit friends.
And now you're gonna kill me, is  that it?
I didn't want it to turn out this  way.
Murphy, don't you see what's  happening?
I think I see it pretty well.
It's the ship. The ship's making you  think this way.
I know a little bit about human nature  and what I've seen only confirms  that.
It's a trap. There was no way we  were gonna get away with that gold.   Nobody ever does. It's just the bait.  This ship sucks people in and it  never lets them out.
I think maybe you been on this boat  a little too long, with all that  supernatural mumbo jumbo. There's  nothing supernatural about greed.   And that's what it comes down to,  pure and simple.
I don't give a damn about the gold.
I wish I could believe that. Either  way, you know what I've done. I've  got no choice. He raises the shotgun.

I'm sorry. He prepares to fire, when a CONCUSSION ROCKS THE SHIP. Ep ducks and Murphy fires, a spatter of buckshot shredding t vent behind her. A SCREECHING OF METAL DEEP IN THE SHIP S as she gets up, diving for cover as Murphy shuttles the g again.
Epps scrambles behind a deck vent.
The ship has bounced off yet another small island, the ja rocks loudly scrapping the hull with a deafening shriek.
Murphy crosses toward the deck vent.
There's no reason to make this any  more difficult than it has to be.
As Epps holds there she sees the vent opening. She pulls  herself up and climbs inside.
Epps climbs down the air shaft where a giant fan spans it width. She squeezes through the fan blades and drops down where several vent ducts lead in different directions bel it.
Murphy comes to the vent duct where Epps went down.
Epps crawls through. She comes to a vent that leads out t passageway.
Murphy runs quickly down the stairway, shotgun at the rea
The vent is shoved out and falls to the metal catwalk.
The CLANG FROM THE VENT SOUNDS HERE and Murphy stops.
Epps extends her feet and climbs down into the passage.
Murphy rounds the corner, moving on the same deck.

Epps moves along on a metal catwalk in the darkness when  something can be heard ahead of her. She stops. FOOTSTEPS SOUND at the end of the passage. Epps pulls bac into the shadows, holding there. The footsteps sound as if they are coming down stairs at other end, when the FOOTSTEPS STOP. Epps holds there, listening intently in the silence when, the other end, THE SOUND OF CREAKING METAL, as from a hat slowly opening, can be heard. It stops. All is silent, WH THE HATCH CREAKS AGAIN at the other end. She begins movin toward it. As she approaches, she can see that the hatch is half ope swaying slightly with the movement of the ship. A CREAKING SOUNDS behind her. She turns, just as Murphy s into view. She ducks as he fires and a spray of buckshot  ricochets off the metal around her. She scrambles on her belly as Murphy fires again. She swi down from the catwalk, letting herself fall to the next d
Epps gets up, runs.
Murphy climbs down a ladder to the lower decks.
Epps moves quickly along.
Murphy follows, when A RUMBLING SOUND CAN BE HEARD.

Epps stops where she is in the cavernous engine room, loo on at the massive hull rising above her as the RUMBLING G IN INTENSITY. Though it seems to resonate throughout the  ship, it seems to originate from here, from directly belo as though the hull were being dragged over a rocky bottom She steps back as the sound grows still louder, until it  becomes absolutely deafening. The ship begins to shudder. The steel bulkheads visibly m and the steel plates in the hull can be seen to bend back and forth.
Murphy slows and finally stops.

A few rivets pop in the hull. Then a few more, as the RUM GROWS STILL LOUDER. Epps puts her hands to her ears and begins to back away,  when the RUMBLING REACHES A PINNACLE.
